0.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has been conversing. They mock his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying that they abhor 'such rackers of orthography' . Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that the King has asked him to prepare 'some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antick or firework'  to entertain the Princess and her party. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests that they present a show of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then go off to plan their show.

2.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado. Nathaniel had questioned him before. They laugh at his weak intellect, mock his pronunciation, and express their disgust for 'such distorters of orthography'. Don Armado, Moth, and Costard enter. Armado informs the scholars that the King has asked them to prepare 'some delightful entertainment, or show, or pageant, or farce, or fireworks' to amuse the Princess and her suite. He asks for Holofernes' and Nathaniel's help in preparing this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests mounting a production of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss the roles the Worthies will play, Holofernes claiming he will take three roles himself. Then they leave to plan their production.

0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text: Jim and the Harling children are happiest and most contented in the spring, playing peacefully in the garden. They are unaware yet that summer will bring changes. As summer approaches, Italians arrive in the town and set up a dance pavilion on an empty lot. They begin giving dance lessons to children, and people start gathering and mingling around the lot. Now there's something to do and a place to socialize. Dancing becomes the craze of the town, and every Saturday night welcomes a grand late-night dance. Jim attends each time, as do many girls and boys from the countryside. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny gain notoriety as 'rented girls' and are always present at the dances.

4.text:
Jim and the Harling children are happiest and most content in the spring, peacefully playing in the garden. They have no idea that summer will bring changes. As summer approaches, Italians arrive in the village and set up a dance pavilion on an empty lot. They begin giving dance lessons to the children, and people start gathering and mingling around the lot. There's something to do and a place to socialize now. Dancing becomes the village's craze, and every Saturday night welcomes a grand nighttime dance party. Jim attends every time, as do many young girls and boys from the countryside. At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny gain popularity and are known as 'dance performers' or 'rent-a-dancers,' and they are always present at the dance parties.

Translation:

Jim and the Harling children are the happiest and most content in the spring, enjoying themselves peacefully in the garden. They have no idea that summer will bring changes. As summer nears, Italians arrive in the village and set up a dance pavilion on an empty plot of land. They begin giving dance lessons to the children, and people start gathering and mingling around the lot. There's something to do and a place to socialize now. Dancing becomes the village's obsession, and every Saturday night hosts a grand nighttime dance party. Jim attends every time, as do many young girls and boys from the countryside. At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become popular and are known as 'dance performers' or 'rent-a-dancers,' and they are always present at the dance parties.

As summer draws near, Italians arrive in the village and build a dance hall on an empty field. They begin to give dance lessons to children, and the population gathers and socializes around this place. There is always an activity to join and a place to meet. The charming dance has enchanted the village, and every Saturday night welcomes a grand dance party. Jim attends each time, accompanied by numerous local children and young girls and boys. At that time, Antonia, Lena and Tiny had gained popularity and were called the 'dance masters' or 'tenants of the dance hall,' and they were always present at the dance parties.

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

2.text: Elizabeth read Darcy's letter with a mix of emotions. At first, upon reading Darcy's explanation of his behavior towards Bingley and Jane, she had doubts about his concern regarding Jane's indifference and believed it was merely because of their connection. However, as she began to read his account of affairs with Wickham, she paid closer attention. She soon realized she knew nothing about Wickham before the night he had informed her of the events between them, and she wondered why she had not noticed his inappropriateness in speaking of such matters to a stranger. Continuing to read and ponder, she came to the conclusion that she was 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believed Darcy's account of the events. Then she re-read the section on Jane and Bingley, and saw that she could not deny the justice of his description of Jane's apparent indifference. After two hours of walking in the park, she returned home to find that Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to take their leave.

0.text: Cunegonde tells her story to Candide: Bulgar soldiers attack and kill her family and rape her. While Cunegonde fights off her attacker, a captain comes in and, enraged at the officer's disrespect, kills him. He then takes Cunegonde as a prisoner of war. The captain keeps Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sells her to a Jewish businessman. The businessman shares her services with the same Inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and flogging of Candide. Cunegonde wards off the sexual advances of both men. Cunegonde attends the post-earthquake execution and recognizes Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. Back in the present, Candide and Cunegonde eat dinner together and hang out until one of her owners, the businessman Don Issachar, comes to get her.

2.text:
Cunegonde tells her story to Candide: Bulgarian soldiers attack and kill her family while raping her. In the struggle against her attacker, a captain is repulsed by the insolence of the officer and kills him. The captain then makes Cunegonde a prisoner of war. She remains his servant for three months and is eventually sold to a Jewish merchant. This merchant shares her services with the same Inquisitor who had ordered the execution of Pangloss and Candide's flogging. Cunegonde manages to defend herself against the advances of these two men. Cunegonde relates the end of her tale here. In the present, Candide and Cunegonde eat together and pass the time until one of her owners, the merchant Don Issachar, returns to claim her.

65.text:
Cungonde tells Candide: Bulgarian soldiers kill and rape her family. In the struggle against her attacker, a captain is overthrown and killed by an officers' mutiny. Cungonde is held captive by this captain. She remains imprisoned for three months before being sold to a Jewish merchant. This merchant lives with Cungonde, the same Inquisitor who had ordered the execution of Pangloss and who had struck Candide. Cungonde rejects them both. Her story ends here.

0.text: Jane and Rochester have a quiet wedding three days after that. Diana and Mary are happy for her and say they will come to visit. St. John did not reply to the letter Jane sent to him regarding the wedding; however, he has since maintained a correspondence with her. Jane goes to see Adele and changes her school for a better and closer one. Jane then tells the reader that it has been ten years now that she has been married as she sits to write about her life. She and Rochester are always together, and after two years, he had regained sight in one of his eyes, enough to see his first-born son. Diana and Mary are both married and come to visit Jane, and she visits them. St. John went to India and is still there. He remained unmarried, and Jane relates that he feels that he will soon die and join God

0.text: Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, followed by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. Sir John orders Bardolph to replenish his supply of sack and to tell Peto to meet him at the town's end. He dislikes the idea of marching his men through the town in their rags and tatters. Abjectly impoverished, not one of them could pay him, as so many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye hath seen such scarecrows' . Prince Hal and Westmoreland meet him on the road and comment on the poor creatures whom Falstaff leads. The knight remains undisturbed and is philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, for that matter, the prince seems amused rather than indignant. All are to make haste, says Hal, for Percy is already in the field.

2.text:
Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, accompanied by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. John Falstaff orders Bardolph to restock his supply of sack and to meet Peto at the end of the town. He dislikes the idea of marching his poor men through the town in their rags and tatters, as none of them could pay him, as many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye has seen such ragged creatures' . Prince Hal and Westmoreland come across them on the road and comment on the pitiful figures that Falstaff is leading. The knight remains unruffled and philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, indeed, the prince seems more amused than indignant. They all need to hurry, Hal reminds them, as Percy is already on the battlefield.

Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, accompanied by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. He dislikes the idea of marching his impoverished men through the town in their rags and tatters, as none of them could pay him, as many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye has seen such ragged creatures' . Hal and Westmoreland encounter Falstaff and his men on the road and remark upon the pitiful appearance of the soldiers under his command. The knight remains unperturbed and philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, indeed, the prince seems more amused than indignant. They must hurry, Hal reminds them, as Percy is already on the battlefield.

4.text: Falstaff orders Bardolph to replenish his sack and meet Peto at the town's end. Falstaff dislikes leading his ragged soldiers through the town, as none could pay him to be excused from military service like others had. Falstaff remarks, 'No eye has seen such tattered creatures' . Hal and Westmoreland encounter Falstaff and his men on the road, commenting on the pitiful state of the soldiers under his command. The knight remains unperturbed and philosophical towards the criticism. In fact, the prince appears more amused than indignant. They need to hurry, Hal reminds them, as Percy is already on the battlefield.

6.text: Falstaff orders Bardolph to restock his bag and make his way towards Peto's vicinity near the city. Falstaff intends to parade his ragged soldiers through the town, as none of them had managed to pay their way out of military service, like others had. Falstaff remarks, 'No eyes have seen such ragged creatures.' Hal and Westmoreland cross paths with Falstaff and his men along the road, expressing pity for the pitiful state of the soldiers under his command. Falstaff remains unmoved and contemplative in the face of criticism. In truth, the prince seems more amused than hurt. Come on, Hal urges, as Percy is already on the battlefield.

8.text: Falstaff orders Bardolph to restock his pouch and make his way to Peto, near the city. Falstaff intends to parade his motley soldiers through the city, as none of them had succeeded in paying their military discharge, like others. Falstaff remarks: 'No eyes have seen such motley creatures.' Hal and Westmoreland cross paths with Falstaff and his men along the road, expressing regret for the pitiful state of the soldiers under his command. Falstaff remains unmoved and contemplative in the face of criticism. In reality, the prince seems more amused than hurt. Now, Urge Hal, Percy is already on the battlefield. (Note: This translation is intended to be as literal as possible while preserving the original meaning and context. It may not read as smoothly in English as in French.)

0.text: Now that he has felt the pain of losing his son, Siddhartha has more sympathy with the needs and desires of ordinary people. He again decides to seek his son in the town, but stops when he thinks he hears a special message from the river. He remembers when he rebelled against his own father, and realizes that his father must have suffered the same pain as he, Siddhartha, suffers now. Sorrows repeat themselves. Still suffering, he returns to the hut and tells Vasudeva of his troubles. Vasudeva, in his silent attentiveness, seems to Siddhartha like a god. They both go and sit by the river bank. Siddhartha practices his technique of listening to the river and realizes the unity of all life amidst all its diverse elements. He realizes that in the unity is perfection. His pain disappears as his Self merges with the unity. From that moment on, Siddhartha no longer fights against his destiny. He accepts everything. Vasudeva, now that he has seen his friend attain enlightenment, announces that he is leaving. He is going to live in the woods and be in the unity of all things.

2.text: his technique of listening to the river and realizes the unity of all life in all its diversities. In unity, there is perfect harmony. His pain disappears when his self merges with the unity. He will live in the forest and be in unity with all.

He will live in the forest and be one with all.

0.text: Salisbury, Pembroke, and Lord Bigot come onstage. The battle is still raging. The dudes can't believe that King John's forces are still standing strong. That said, they thinks it's awesome that King John had to leave the battle with a doctor's note. Just then, in comes the French Count Melun, who's trying to hold his guts so they don't fall out of his body. Melun tells the English lords to abandon their rebellion and swear allegiance to King John once more, because if the French and the rebels defeat King John, Louis the Dauphin plans to have all his English allies beheaded. At first, Salisbury can't believe him. But then Melun explains that he is about to die, anyway, and he'll get a better reward in heaven by telling the truth now than by keeping mum. Anyway, he explains, his grandfather was English, so he has some sympathy for them. Salisbury definitely doesn't want to get his head lopped off, so he decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the other English nobles leave the stage, taking Melun with them.

2.text: Salisbury, Pembroke, and Lord Bigot appear. The battle continues. The knights are surprised that the forces of John Lackland persist in resisting. In fact, they are astonished that John Lackland had to leave the battlefield due to a medical report. Then, the Count of Melun, the Frenchman, enters the scene, attempting to keep his intestines in his body. Melun calls upon the English lords to abandon their rebellion and swear allegiance to John Lackland once more, for, if the French and rebels defeat John Lackland, Louis the Dauphin intends to behead all his English allies. Initially, Salisbury finds this hard to believe. But later, Melun explains that he is going to die somewhere and will receive a better reward in hell by telling the truth now rather than keeping it hidden. Moreover, he adds, his grandfather was English, so he has some sympathy for them. Salisbury has no desire to lose his head, so he decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the other English lords exit the scene, taking Melun with them.

0.text: There is much speculation at the training college when Sue does not return that evening at prayer time. Everyone wonders about the young man she has gone out with, and some of them are convinced that Jude is only posing as her cousin. The situation takes a serious turn because a similar incident occurred the year before: a young man had managed to seduce a student of the same college, maintaining that he was her cousin. The mistress inquires about the two photographs on Sue's dressing table. One is of Mr. Phillotson, and the other is of an unknown undergraduate. The next morning, when Sue does return, she is punished and kept in solitary confinement. The other students feel the punishment is too harsh and prepare to protest. In the evening it is discovered that Sue has escaped from a back window. She turns up at Jude's place. She is soaked and shivering with cold. Jude immediately takes her in and offers her some dry clothes and brandy. Sue is so tired that she falls asleep while relating her story.

The ailing earl laments that he treated Edgar badly and wishes for the opportunity to once again touch his son, since he can no longer see him. Gloucester hears Edgar's voice and remembers Poor Tom from the night of the storm. In an act of humanity, Gloucester sends his tenant for some clothing so that the Bedlam beggar might be covered. Gloucester is concerned that the Old Man might suffer for having given assistance, so he dismisses him and asks Tom to be his guide to Dover, where he seeks the highest cliff. Tom agrees to take Gloucester to the cliff.

0.text: Frank Churchill writes to say that he cannot come to visit after all, and Mrs. Weston is disappointed. Emma and Mr. Knightley disagree about him, Knightley arguing that he is a young man can do what he sets his mind to and is just making excuses, and Emma defending him, saying that he is too much in debt to his aunt and uncle to disobey their wishes. He says that his letters are full of himself and of falsehood, and when Emma says that they seem to satisfy everyone else, he asserts that they cannot be satisfying Mrs. Weston, who must be feeling the omission of his not visiting. Emma thinks that Mr. Knightley is prejudiced against Frank Churchill

2.text: Frank Churchill informs us now that he won't be able to visit us, and Madame Weston is disappointed. Emma and Mr. Knightley have differing opinions about him: Knightley states that he's a young man who does as he pleases and apologizes for it, and Emma defends him, saying that he's deeply in debt to his aunt and uncle and can't disobey their wishes. He asserts that his letters are full of himself and lies, and when Emma says they seem to please everyone else, he asserts that they can't please Madame Weston, who feels the absence of his visit. Emma thinks Mr. Knightley has a bias against Frank Churchill.

0.text: The next morning Mr. Gardiner starts off for London when no letter from Mr. Bennet arrives. Mrs. Gardiner and the children decide to stay in Longbourn for a few days to try to help, and on Tuesday she receives a letter from her husband saying that he and Mr. Bennet are searching the hotels in town for Lydia and Wickham. A letter soon arrives from Mr. Collins saying that he has heard of their misfortune, and writing Mr. Bennet that it would be best for him to 'throw off your unworthy child from your affections for ever. Mr. Gardiner writes again saying he has no news yet other than that Wickham does not seem to have any family or friends that they could be staying with, and that he left a number of gambling debts in Brighton. Mr. Bennet returns home, and Mrs. Gardiner and her children leave. Mr. Bennet tells Elizabeth that she was justified in her advice to him before Lydia left, and that he has learnt to be cautious about his daughters

2.text: The morning after, Mr. Gardiner departs from London without a letter from Mr. Bennet. Mrs. Gardiner and their children choose to remain at Longbourn for some additional days to render assistance. On Tuesday, she obtains a letter from her husband, enlightening them and Mr. Bennet that they are actively searching the city's inns for Lydia and Wickham. Shortly thereafter, a letter arrives from Mr. Collins, conveying his condolences for their misfortune and advising Mr. Bennet to 'completely sever your ties with your unworthy daughter.' Mr. Gardiner responds, providing no new information except for Wickham seemingly lacking family or friends to receive them and having overdue gambling debts in Brighton. Mr. Bennet makes his way back home, and Mrs. Gardiner and their children depart. Mr. Bennet imparts to Elizabeth that your counsel was astute before Lydia's departure, and that he now grasps the significance of vigilance concerning his daughters.

4.text:
M. Bennet. Madame Gardiner et leurs enfants dcident de rester  Longbourn quelques jours de plus pour fournir de l'aide. Le mardi, elle reoit une lettre de son mari, qui leur informe et  M. Bennet que ils recherchent activement Lydia et Wickham dans les auberges de la ville. Couramment aprs, une lettre arrive de M. Collins, qui exprime ses condolances pour leur malheur et conseille  M. Bennet de 'complter les liens avec sa fille indigne.' M. 0.text: Scrooge wakes up in his bedroom and joyfully repeats his vow to live from the lessons of the three ghosts. He runs around his house and then outside, where church bells ring. A boy tells him it is Christmas Day, and Scrooge realizes that the ghosts visited him all in one night. Scrooge buys a prize turkey and sends it to Bob Cratchit's house. Scrooge dresses in his best clothing and walks in the crowds with a smile. He gives a great deal of money to the portly gentleman who had asked him for a charitable donation yesterday. Scrooge continues to walk through the city and happily talks with everyone he meets. He visits Fred's house and has a wonderful time at the party. The next morning, Scrooge gets to work early. When Cratchit comes in late, Scrooge pretends to reprimand him, then gives him a raise. Scrooge continues his kindly ways, befriending everyone and becoming a second father to Tiny Tim, who does not die. He never sees the ghosts again, but he keeps the spirit of Christmas alive in his heart as well as anyone.

2.text:
Scrooge se rveille dans sa chambre, se rjouit joyeusement en rptant son vu de vivre selon les leons des trois fantmes. Il courre dans sa maison et ensuite dehors, o sonnent les cloches de l'glise. Un garon lui dit que c'est Nol, et Scrooge ralise que les fantmes lui ont visit toute la nuit. Scrooge achte une oie de Nol  prix rduit et l'envoie  la maison de Bob Cratchit. Scrooge se habille dans ses meilleures tenues et marche parmi la foule avec un sourire. Il donne une grande somme d'argent au gros gentilhomme qui lui avait demand une contribution charitable hier. Scrooge continue de marcher dans la ville et parle joyeusement  tous ceux qu'il rencontre. Il visite la maison de Fred et a une merveilleuse fois  la fte. Le matin suivant, Scrooge arrive tt au travail. Quand Archibald arrive en retard, Scrooge simule de l'encourager, puis lui donne une augmentation. Scrooge continue  agir ainsi, devenant une figure paternelle secondaire pour Tiny Tim, qui ne meurt pas. Il ne voit plus les fantmes, mais garde le esprit de Nol vivant en lui, comme quelqu'un d'autre.

Translation note: In the translation, I assumed that the names 'Scrooge,' 'Bob Cratchit,' 'Archie,' and 'Fred' were given in English in the original text and should be translated letter-for-letter into French as 'Scrooge,' 'Bob Cratchit,' 'Archibald,' and 'Fred,' respectively. If these names have French translations, then they should be used instead.

4.text:
Scrooge wakes up in his room, happily rejoicing and repeating his pledge to live according to the lessons of the three spirits. He then runs through his house and outside, where church bells are ringing. A boy tells him it's Christmas, and Scrooge realizes they had visited him all night. Scrooge buys a cheap turkey for the Cratchit family and sends it to them. Scrooge puts on his finest clothes and mingles with the crowd with a smile. He makes a generous donation to the kind man who asked for a charitable contribution the day before. Scrooge continues walking through the city, spreading joy to everyone he encounters. He visits Fred's home and enjoys himself immensely at the gathering. The following morning, Scrooge arrives at work earlier than usual. When Archibald is late, Scrooge motivates him and grants him a raise. Scrooge continues behaving this way, becoming a secondary father figure for Tiny Tim, who survives.

0.text: Sara may be a weird kid, but Ermengarde St. John has a decidedly weird name. She's not super smart, poor thing, and is blown away by Sara's ability to learn French. Miss Minchin isn't very nice to Ermengarde, and because of this, Sara feels the need to reach out to her. After lessons, Sara introduces herself. Ermengarde goes on about how clever Sara must be because she can speak French. Sara does what any child would upon making a friend --she asks Ermengarde if she'd like to meet Emily, her doll. When she starts to tell fantastical stories about Emily, Ermengarde is amazed at how she's able to just make things up on the fly. Suddenly, Sara looks like she's in pain. Ermengarde asks her what is up with that, and Sara responds that she's in pain because she misses her father. Then, Ermengarde asks Sara if she'd like to be her best friend. Which is not weird at all. Sara agrees. Yay, BFF!

2.text:
Saras could be a somewhat strange child, but Ermengarde St. John has an unusually strange name. She's not particularly intelligent, thankfully, and is surprised by Sara's mastery of French. Mme Minchin is not kind to Ermengarde, so Sara feels obliged to approach her. After lessons, Sara draws attention to herself. Ermengarde is amazed by Sara's intelligence due to her French skills. Sara behaves like any other child when meeting a friend  she offers Ermengarde a chance to meet Emily, her doll. When she starts telling fantastic stories about Emily, Ermengarde is surprised by Sara's creativity. Suddenly, Sara seems to be in pain. Ermengarde asks what's wrong, and Sara reveals that she's in pain because she misses her father. Then, Ermengarde asks if Sara would have liked her to be her best friend. That's not strange at all. Sara agrees. Long live the French best friends!

(Note: In this English translation, I have tried to preserve the original meaning and context as closely as possible. I have assumed that 'Miss Minchin' was a title and translated it as 'Mme Minchin' in the English version. Also, I translated 'BFF' as 'French best friend' to maintain the original context.)

Saras pouvait tre un enfant un peu trange, mais Ermengarde St. John a un nom particulirement trange. 0.text: Mr. Micawber's Transactions Mr. Micawber, who thinks the move to Australia may be exactly what his family needs, wants to be sure that he arranges the finances between him and Miss Betsey professionally. Mrs. Micawber is very concerned that Mr. Micawber should repair her relationship with her family before they leave. Agnes, Traddles, David, and Miss Betsey meet to discuss the Micawbers' finances. Traddles has discovered that he can recover all of Miss Betsey's money as well as Mr. Wickfield's. Agnes says she will rent out the house and run a school in order to keep herself and her father financially secure. David, meanwhile, decides he will go abroad. Traddles reports that Uriah has left town with his mother, and no one knows what has become of him. Arrangements are made to provide for the Micawbers' debts and raise enough money to get them to Australia. Two days later, Miss Betsey takes David to a hospital and to a funeral. She tells him that her husband has died, and that he will not be a threat to her anymore

0.text: We begin with a prologue. An actor dressed in armor comes out on stage and welcomes us to ancient Troy, where the Greeks and Trojans have been going at it on the Trojan battlefields for the last...get this...7 years. Since we're starting out 'in the middle' of all the action, the Prologue quickly catches us up to speed. You know, just in case we've never heard of a little old thing called the Trojan War. Here are the deets: the Greeks have sailed across the 'Athenian Bay' to 'ransack' Troy because a Trojan Prince named Paris stole Helen from the Greek King Menelaus and has been sleeping with her ever since. Simple as that. Next, the Prologue warns us that we might not like the play because nothing good ever really happens in times of 'war.' By the way, Shmooperinos, the Prologue says absolutely NOTHING about Troilus and Cressida, the two characters Shakespeare named this play after. What's up with that?

2.text:
We begin with a prologue. An actor in armor steps onto the stage and welcomes us to Troy, where the Greeks and Trojans have been fighting each other on the Trojan battlefields for about 7 years now. The Prologue quickly brings us up to speed. In short, for those of us who know nothing about it, here's what's happening: The Greeks crossed the 'Bay of Athena' to sack Troy because a Trojan prince named Paris stole Helen, queen of the Greeks, from Menelaus, king of the Greeks, and has been living with her ever since. Nothing more complicated than that. The Prologue then warns us that we might not like the play because nothing good happens during 'the wars.' Moreover, the Prologue says nothing at all about the characters Troilus and Cressida, to whom Shakespeare gave the name of the play. So, what's the point?

Translation:
Nous commenons par un prologue. Un acteur en armure monte sur scne et nous accueille  Troy, o les Grecs et les Trojiens se battent depuis...environ 7 ans sur les champs de bataille trojiens. Le Prologue nous met rapidement au courant. En un mot, pour ceux d'entre nous qui ne savent rien, voici ce qui se passe : Les Grecs ont travers la 'baie d'Athna' pour piller Troy parce qu'un prince trojan nomm Paris a vol Hlne, reine des Grecs,  Menelaus, roi des Grecs, et vit avec elle depuis. Rien de plus complexe  cela. Le Prologue nous avertit ensuite que nous pourrions ne pas apprcier la pice car rien de bien ne se produit durant 'les guerres'. De plus, le Prologue ne dit rien du tout des personnages Troilus et Cressida, auxquels Shakespeare a donn le nom  la pice. Donc, qu'est-ce que c'est pour cela ?

Mrs. Weston opposes this view, believing that Emma needs Harriet's friendship and will benefit from it. She advises Emma to remain silent, and the conversation ends with reflections on Emma's future. In expressing his intention never to marry and the scant number of suitors remaining, Mr. Knightley states: 'I can easily imagine Emma in love and hesitant; it would do her good.'

0.text: Elizabeth, rambling in the park, often meets Darcy unexpectedly. On these occasions, he walks with her and asks odd questions about her likes and dislikes. Once she meets Fitzwilliam while she is strolling, and they speak of Darcy. Fitzwilliam tells her that recently Darcy has saved a friend from an unwise marriage, and he suspects this friend to be Bingley. Elizabeth is pained over hearing the news. She is furious with Darcy for ruining her sisters life. She later feigns a headache so she will not have to accompany the others to Rosings; angry with Darcy for his interference in Janes life, she does not want to see him.

Elizabeth is moved by this news. She is furious at Darcy for ruining her sister's life. Later, to avoid further encounters and not see him, she feigns illness and refuses to go to Rosings.

0.text: According to Dr. Barlow's instructions, Dylan leads Alek to the machine rooms to check on the secret cargo. Dylan and Alek get into a tiff, but then they make up and Dylan explains a lot about the airship. Then they get into another tiff about which is better: machines or fabricated beasts. The two of them check the temperature of the eggs, grab the supplies Dylan left in the machine room earlier, and head to the sick bay. Dylan thanks Alek for saving him from frostbite--in a roundabout way, of course. On the way to sick bay, Dylan and Alek talk about how important Alek thinks he is, and Dylan reveals that his mother didn't want him to be a soldier. All this bickering and sharing of confidences means the two are well on their way to becoming friends.

0.text: Hamilton defends the treaty-making procedures outlined in the Constitution. He responds to the criticism that the Constitution wrongly mixes the legislative and executive branches of government by affording both a role in making and approving treaties. Hamilton argues that act of treaty-making does not fit neatly into the typical purview of either the executive or legislative branch. Therefore, affording a role to both is appropriate. Other critics claimed that the power to make treaties should be limited to the president. Hamilton responds that, unlike European monarchs, the president is only in office for a limited period of time. He may therefore be tempted to sign a treaty detrimental to the nation but beneficial to his private interests since he will eventually return to being a private citizen . It is therefore necessary that his power be held in check by the legislature. Others asserted that the Congress should have even greater authority over treaty making. However, Hamilton responds that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies to the process and weaken the American negotiating position.

2.text: Through the legislative branch. Some have argued that Congress should have more authority over treaties. However, Hamilton counters that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies into the process and weaken the United States' negotiating position.

4.text: Through the legislative branch. Some have claimed that Congress should have more authority over treaties. However, Hamilton argues against this, stating that it would introduce unwarranted delays and inefficiencies into the process and weaken the bargaining power of the United States.

0.text: Linda and Mrs. Bruce go off on vacation, and Linda experiences plenty of ugly prejudice, even though she's working as a nurse for Mrs. Bruce's child. Like: The waiters won't give her tea when she's eating with Mrs. Bruce. She's not allowed to sit in a chair and hold the child on her lap, but has to place the child in the chair and stand behind her. The servants won't bring her dinner to her room when Mrs. Bruce asks them to, so she has to go down to the kitchen to get it herself. Finally, Linda puts her foot down and says that Mrs. Bruce is paying for her just like any of the white servants, so she'd better be treated like one of them. This actually works. See, Linda says, you've just got to stand up for your rights.

2.text:
Linda and Mrs. Bruce are on vacation, but Linda is subjected to numerous unfair prejudices, despite working as a nurse for Mrs. Bruce's child. For instance: The waiters do not bring her tea when she eats with Mrs. Bruce. She is not allowed to sit on a chair and hold the child on her lap, instead she has to put the child in the chair and sit behind it. The domestic staff do not bring her meal to her room when Mrs. Bruce asks for it, so she has to go to the kitchen to get it herself. In the end, Linda defends herself and tells Mrs. Bruce that she is paid like any other female worker, and therefore should be treated accordingly. 'Look,' she says, 'you don't need to fight for your rights.'

Translation:

Linda and Mrs. Bruce go on vacation, but Linda experiences many unfair prejudices, despite working as a nurse for Mrs. Bruce's child. For example: The waiters do not bring her tea when she eats with Mrs. Bruce. She is not allowed to sit on a chair and hold the child on her lap, instead she has to put the child in the chair and sit behind it. The domestic staff do not bring her meal to her room when Mrs. Bruce asks for it, so she has to go to the kitchen to get it herself. Jane meets Diana and Mary, who admire her drawings and give her books to read. However, St. John keeps his distance and remains aloof, yet never impolite. Her sisters suspect that St. John is about to leave England for a foreign mission. 0.text: Over two years have passed. Jude and Sue lead a wandering life, stopping wherever Jude can find work as a mason. However, he refuses to do any church work. At the little town of Kennetbridge, Arabella and Anny arrive one day. Arabella is now widowed and is in mourning and has come to Kennetbridge to see the laying of a foundation stone of a new chapel. She claims that she has now turned to religion for consolation. She suddenly spots Sue and Little Father Time selling cakes and gingerbread at a stall at the fair. She questions Sue and learns that Jude was very ill that winter, and they have therefore tried their hand at baking in an attempt to earn a living. Sue now has two children of her own and is expecting a third. The cakes Jude makes are shaped like Christminster colleges, with towers and pinnacles and traceried windows, indicating that Jude still has a passion for Christminster.

Suddenly, Sue and 'Father Time' (Father Time) appeared before their bakery at the market. Arabella asked Sue where Jude lived during the winter. She learned that, being ill, Jude earned a living by baking cakes. Now, Sue had two children and was pregnant with a third. Jude's cakes had a distinctive appearance, reminiscent of Christminster with its towers, bells, and sculpted windows, reflecting Jude's unwavering devotion to Christminster.

0.text: A French Lord holds a showcase Extravaganza where all the important aristocrats attend. The host snubs the Marquis St. Evremonde and he leaves the reception angrily, ordering his driver to race through the Paris streets. He accidentally runs over a child whose father is Gaspard. He tosses the grief-stricken father a coin and Defarge emerges from the crowd to comfort Gaspard. He throws the coin back into the carriage as it speeds away. The Marquis travels to his country estate where he stops at the village he owns, near his home. A road mender claims he saw a man riding underneath the carriage, who, when it stopped, ran away. The Marquis tells Gabelle, the town official, to be on the lookout for the mystery man. The Marquis travels on to his chateau hoping to meet his nephew M. Charles who is traveling from England.

0.text: Everyone in the walker debates what to do, but no one knows what to do except Deryn, who asks Alek for an axe. They have to move the walker fast, so Deryn runs back to the chain and tries to cut the sleigh free. She manages to free the sleigh, but the momentum starts the sleigh down the slope toward the walker. Riding the sleigh, Deryn yells for Dr. Barlow, who comes out and realizes what's happening. Deryn rides the sleigh toward the walker, hoping the two don't collide with her in the middle. Dr. Barlow throws out the ladder from the walker's belly, indicating that Deryn should grab it and climb aboard. As she passes the walker, Deryn leaps for the ladder, catches it, and Bauer and Hoffman help her aboard.

2.text:
All those in the group are animatedly discussing what needs to be done, but none of them really know what needs to be done except Deryn, who asks Alek for an ax. They need to move the group quickly, so Deryn runs back to the chain and tries to free the cart. She manages to free it, but the movement causes it to roll towards the group, down the slope. Deryn climbs onto the cart, calling for Dr. Barlow, who comes out and understands the situation. Deryn drives the cart towards the group, hoping they won't collide in the middle. Dr. Barlow throws the ladder from the belly of the group, indicating for Deryn to grab it and climb up. As she passes in front of the group, Deryn jumps onto the ladder, grabs it, and Bauer and Hoffman help her up.

(Note: In the translation, I assumed 'group' referred to a team or a collective, and 'belly' referred to the bottom or the underside of the group, as in a group of people gathered together. If these meanings are incorrect, please let me know and I will adjust the translation accordingly.)

0.text: The Squire comes to the Poysers to ask them to give up some of their farming land in exchange for some additional dairy land. The Squire wants the arrangement so that he can lease Chase Farm, and he flatters and wheedles in his attempt to get the Poysers to agree. Mrs. Poyser is furious and refuses the offer. She says she will not help him make more money while ruining herself. Mr. Poyser worries that he will kick them off Hall Farm when it comes time to renew their lease. He laments the idea of going to live among strangers when it has been the pride of his family that they have land. Mrs. Poyser tells him not to worry about that until it happens

2.text: The Knight comes to the Poysers to propose they give up a part of their agricultural lands in exchange for additional dairy lands. The Knight intends to rent Farm Chase and tries to persuade them by flattering and maneuvering. Madame Poyer is furious and rejects the offer. She states she would not do it to help him earn more money at their expense. Monsieur Poyser is concerned they will be evicted from Hall Farm when the lease is renewed. He regrets the idea of having to live among strangers since land ownership is a source of pride for his family. Madame Poyer asks him not to worry until things are clearer.

He regrets the idea of having to live among strangers since the ownership of the land is a source of pride for his family. Madame Poyer asks him not to worry until things are clearer.

0.text: The mayoral election comes up for Zenith, and the left-wing lawyer Seneca Doane is running. That means that Babbitt and his pro-business brotherhood need to fire up their election machine and get anyone other than Doane into office. They promote a candidate named Lucas Prout and Babbitt goes around giving speeches in support of Prout. Ultimately, Babbitt's efforts are able to get Lucas Prout elected mayor. The business community survives another big scare from organized labor. Now that he has an established reputation as a speechmaker, Babbitt is invited to all sorts of functions to give speeches about business and about the glory of Zenith. One of the main points in his speeches is that state universities should fire all professors who preach liberal or socialist views. As his star continues to rise in Zenith's social circles, Babbitt wonders how he ever could have doubted the joys of being a solid citizen.

2.text:
The municipal election in Zenith is approaching and Seneca Doane, a left-wing lawyer, has announced his candidacy. This means that Babbitt and his business associates must set their electoral machine in motion and find an alternative to Doane. They support a candidate named Lucas Prout, and Babbitt gives speeches for Prout everywhere. In the end, Babbitt's efforts contribute to Prout's election as mayor. The business community manages to overcome another major threat from the labor organization. With his well-established reputation as a speaker, Babbitt is invited to many events to give speeches on business and Zenith's prosperity. A recurring theme in his speeches is the call for the suppression of state-funded teachers teaching liberal or socialist ideas. As Babbitt's reputation in Zenith's social circles continues to improve, he wonders how he could have once questioned the joys of responsible citizenship.

Translation:

The municipal election in Zenith is drawing near, and Seneca Doane, a left-wing lawyer, has declared his candidacy. Consequently, Babbitt and his business partners must activate their electoral machinery and find a replacement for Doane. They back a candidate named Lucas Prout, and Babbitt delivers speeches for Prout at various venues. Ultimately, Babbitt's efforts play a significant role in Prout's election as mayor. The business community manages to fend off another major threat from the labor union. Given his well-established reputation as an orator, Babbitt is invited to numerous events to deliver speeches on business and Zenith's prosperity. A common theme in his speeches is the advocacy for the elimination of teachers funded by the state who espouse liberal or socialist ideologies. As Babbitt's standing in Zenith's social circles continues to rise, he ponders how he could have once pondered the pleasures of exhibiting responsible citizenship.

They support a candidate named Lucas Prout, and Babbitt gives speeches for Prout at various locations. In the end, Babbitt's efforts prove decisive in Prout's election as mayor. 0.text: The next day, Sue, having changed her mind as usual, writes Jude a note saying he must not come to Shaston. Jude writes back agreeing not to meet her. But on Easter Monday he gets a message from Mrs. Edlin saying that his aunt's health is sinking. Jude rushes to Marygreen to find Aunt Drusilla already dead. He informs Sue, who arrives for the funeral. After the funeral, Sue and Jude have a discussion about Aunt Drusilla's disapproval of marriage for the Fawleys. Sue confesses to an intense physical aversion to Phillotson, although she respects and likes him as a friend. Jude senses her unhappiness and laments the fact that he did not try to prevent her hasty marriage. Sue will not let Jude comfort her and goes off to Widow Edlin's cottage for the night. Later that night, Jude hears the cry of trapped rabbit, and, unable to bear it, he goes out and relieves it of further pain by putting it to death. He finds Sue awake at her window, and she breaks down and pours out all her suffering to him. She finally admits her mistake in not considering the full implications of marriage.

0.text: Once inside the chateau, in his elegant private rooms, the Marquis prepares for supper and awaits his nephew's arrival. When his nephew -- Charles Darnay -- arrives, the two exchange brief formalities and then, after the servants have left, Darnay tells his uncle that he is renouncing all ties to his family and to France. Although he is coolly polite, the Marquis' dislike for his nephew is apparent. Darnay equally despises his uncle, and the fear and hatred inspired by the Evremond name troubles him. Before they part, the Marquis asks about Darnay's relationship with Doctor Manette and Lucie and then smiles mysteriously. In the morning, the Marquis is discovered dead -- stabbed by a member of the Jacquerie.

The she-wolf settles into the lair while One Eye instinctively goes in search of food for the soon-to-arrive pups. After his first foray, he returns with no food, but does find that the she-wolf has given birth. She is at first very protective of the pups, exercising her motherly, instinctual knowledge that the father could be a danger to the newborns. 0.text: The narrator takes the reader to the home of Mr. Aldophous Irwine, the rector of Broxton, where Hayslope is located. Mr. Irwine is playing chess with his mother, Mrs. Irwine, a socialite. Mr. Irwine is a bachelor because he has chosen to take care of his mother and two unmarried sisters, one of whom is chronically ill, rather than have his own family. Joshua Rann, the cobbler and parish clerk of Hayslope, comes to see Mr. Irwine to complain about the Methodists and Dinah. In particular, Mr. Rann complains about the wheelwright, Will Maskery, who is a Methodist and has made disparaging remarks about Mr. Irwine and Rann. Mr. Irwine laughs off the insults and tells Rann to leave Maskery to his own business. As Rann is leaving, Captain Arthur Donnithorne arrives to ask Mr. Irwine to go riding with him. Captain Donnithorne is the grandson and heir of the local landlord, Squire Donnithorne. Known throughout the village as 'the young squire,' he is a dashing man who is staying at the Squire's estate to recover from an injury in the army. Mr. Irwine is a bachelor by choice, as he takes care of his mother and two unmarried sisters, one of whom is chronically ill. Joshua Rann, the parish clerk and carter of Hayslope, comes to see Mr. Irwine to reprimand the Methodists and Dinah. Specifically, Rann scolds Will Maskery, the Methodist carter, for making disparaging remarks about Mr. Irwine and himself. Mr. Irwine laughs off these insults and tells Rann to let Maskery be. When Rann leaves, Captain Arthur Donnithorne arrives to ask Mr. Irwine to go riding with him. Captain Donnithorne is the grandson and heir of the local landowner, Sir Donnithorne. Known in the village as 'the young squire,' he is an attractive man recuperating from injuries sustained in the army. Rann informs both Mr. Irwine and Captain Donnithorne of Thias Bede's death, the father of Adam.

0.text: As this scene opens, Cyrano is in a state of frenzied exhilaration because Roxane has acknowledged his existence. He wishes to prove his worth to her by showing his valor. Two gentlemen, Cuigy and Brissaille, enter with the drunken Ligniere, who declares that a hundred men are waiting to attack him. Cyrano offers to offer him protection, by escorting him with a troop of officers. He declares, however, that he will find the attackers alone and unaided. As they prepare to leave, several others join the group, wishing to witness what happens at the Porte de Nesle. When they depart, Cyrano is proudly at the head of the group. He pauses to say that it was necessary to send one hundred men to kill Ligniere because everyone knows he is a friend of his, implying that everyone fears Cyrano.

0.text: The mender of roads who spotted the man under the Marquis St. Evremonde's carriage accompanies Defarge to the wine-shop. In the garret where Doctor Alexandre Manette stayed, Defarge and Jacques One, Two, and Three listen to the road-mender describe what happened to Gaspard, the man who killed the Marquis. Gaspard, who murdered the Marquis for running down his child, went into hiding for nearly a year after the killing. The French authorities recently captured, jailed, and hanged him, and left his corpse dangling by the village fountain, with his shadow poisoning the atmosphere of the town. Monsieur and Madame Defarge later take the road-mender to Versailles, where the splendor of the court dazzles him. Caught up in the emotion of the experience, the road-mender cheers the King, Queen, and other nobles. The Defarges commend his behavior, feeling that it will fuel the courtiers' arrogance and ignorance of the revolutionary movement. Additionally, the Defarges believe that the sight of such luxury and finery will supply the road-mender with a focus for his hatred and violence in the future.

2.text:
The cart driver who saw the man under Marquis St-Evremonde's cart accompanies Defarge to the wine shop. In the attic where Dr. Alexandre Manette lived, Defarge and Jacques, Two and Three listen to the account of the cart driver regarding the events concerning Gaspard, the man who had killed the Marquis by running over his child. Gaspard, who had killed the Marquis to avenge his child, had hidden for nearly a year after the murder. The French authorities had recently captured, imprisoned, and hanged him, leaving his body hanging near the village fountain, altering the city's mood with the shadow of his corpse. Later, the Defarges take him to Versailles, where the splendor of the court dazzles the cart driver. Taken aback by the sight, the cart driver exclaims upon seeing the King, the Queen, and other nobles. The Defarges pay him homage for his behavior, sensing that it would fan the pride and ignorance of the courtiers towards the revolutionary movement. Moreover, the Defarges believe that the sight of this luxury and refinement will provide the cart driver with a focus for his hatred and violence in the future.

0.text: Fire Rises The French countryside lies ruined and desolate. An unidentified man, weary from travel, meets the mender of roads. They address each other as 'Jacques' to indicate their status as revolutionaries. The mender of roads directs the man to the chateau of the murdered Marquis. Later that night, the man sets the castle on fire. A rider from the chateau urges the village soldiers to help put out the fire and salvage the valuables there, but they refuse, and the villagers go inside their homes and put 'candles in every dull little pane of glass. The peasants nearly kill Gabelle, the local tax collector, but he escapes to the roof of his house, where he watches the chateau burn. The narrator reports that scenes such as this are occurring all over France

2.text: The French peasant is devastated and forsaken. A weary traveler, an unknown man, encounters the highwayman. They greet each other mutually by saying 'Jacques' to signify their affiliation with the revolutionaries. The highwayman guides the man towards the Marquis' castle, which has been assassinated. Later in the night, the man sets the castle on fire. A rider from the castle calls the village soldiers to extinguish it and save the remaining goods, but they refuse. Instead, the peasants go home and put candles in every pane of their dark windows. The peasants prepare to kill Gabelle, the local tax collector, but he escapes onto the roof of his house, where he watches the castle burn. The narrator reports that such scenes occur everywhere in France.

0.text: Ajax and Diomedes run around calling out for Troilus to show his face. So they can smash it in. They bicker about who gets to fight him, until Troilus gets fed up and says that he'll take them both on at the same time.Seriously? Maybe not a good move, dude. They fight their way off the stage as Achilles and Hector show up, going at it with their swords. Hector is getting the better of Achilles and offers to let the guy take a break. This is such a weird battle, you guys. Achilles talks some trash and says something like 'I'll be back' as he runs off. Troilus runs back on stage and says that Ajax has captured Aeneas. He promises to rescue him and runs off. Next, an armored Greek soldier shows up, takes one look at Hector, and hightails it out of there. Hector says he really likes the guy's armor and wouldn't mind having it in his trophy case. Then he runs after the shiny trophy.

2.text:
Ajax and Diomede were running around, shouting loudly for Troilus to show himself. They intended to attack. They argued among themselves as to who had the right to face him, until Troilus grew exhausted and announced that he would face both of them at once.

Serious? Perhaps we should reconsider, my friend. They left the scene bickering, while Achilles and Hector appeared, fighting with their swords. Hector had the advantage over Achilles and offered him a truce. What a fine battle, indeed. Achilles hurled insults and said something like 'I'll be back' before leaving. Troilus returned and announced that Ajax had captured Aeneas. He pledged to free him and had fled. Then, a Greek soldier in armor appeared, saw Hector, and fled. Hector admired the armor of the last man and could not resist the idea of adding it to his treasure. He then set out in pursuit of the magnificent trophy.

0.text: Joe Welling lives with his mother in Winesburg. Though a man of small stature, he is like a 'living volcano'. He is subject to fits of ideas, whereupon he becomes uncontrollable, words spout from his mouth in torrents, and the person who is his victim then has no escape. He works as an agent for the standard Oil Company, but he can accost anyone on the road and rapidly begin shooting words at him. He is a terror for the Winesburg citizens. But when Joe organizes the baseball club, he is considered a savior, as he can channel his ideas and excitement into the players and make them win. Joe falls in love with Sarah king a lean, sad-looking woman. Her brother Tom is considered dangerous, and so is his father Edward, the people of Winesburg can't help laughing at the odd pair but are afraid for Joe. George Willard reports his meeting with the two Kings. Apparently, Joe has managed to sweep away the two, by his torrent of words and ideas. His ideas have managed to perplex the two men and have given them no chance to counter attack Joe.

0.text: In the opening chapter, the period in which the novel is set is described. The story begins about fifteen years before the French Revolution. It is a time when many people think they live in the best of times, while others condemn it as the worst of times. The kings of England and France are both mediocre rulers, and they believe in their divine rights. People are put to death for the slightest of crimes. The condition in France is very bad, for there is a total disregard for the common people by the aristocracy; injustice, cruelty, and oppression are rampant. The aristocracy is unaware that the masses are preparing for the revolution by turning timber into guillotines and farm carts into tumbrels to convey people to the guillotine. In England, too, lawlessness and poverty prevail. Even the colonies in America are up in arms against their English rulers, and the attempts of the American colonies to obtain freedom are not taken seriously.

2.text:
In the opening chapter, the historical period in which the novel is set is described. The story begins roughly fifteen years prior to the French Revolution. It is an era in which many believe they live in the best of times, while others condemn it as the worst. Both the kings of England and France are mediocre rulers, and they believe in their divine rights. People are executed for minor offenses. The situation in France is particularly bad, as there is no respect for the commons of the nobles; injustice, cruelty, and oppression are rampant. The nobility is oblivious to the fact that the masses are preparing a revolution, transforming wood into guillotines and agricultural carts into tumbrels to transport people to the guillotine. In England as well, unrest and poverty reign. The colonies in America rebel against their English governors, and the efforts of the American colonies to obtain their freedom are not taken seriously.

People are put to death for petty offenses. The situation in France is especially dire, as there is no respect for the commons of the nobles; injustice, cruelty, and oppression are rampant. The nobility is unaware that the masses are planning a revolution, turning wood into guillotines and agricultural carts into tumbrels to transport people to the guillotine. In England too, unrest and poverty prevail. The American colonies rebel against their English governors, and their attempts to gain their freedom are dismissed.

0.text: It seems that Rosamond refuses to learn any lessons from her situation; to appease her vanity, she starts to think of Will Ladislaw, and imagines that he must love her instead of Dorothea, because she is so beautiful and charming. She continues to blame her husband for her unhappiness, not her rabid materialism; everything is someone else's fault, and she is still a creature who is perfectly innocent of blame. She gets a letter from Will, saying that he will be paying a visit sometime soon; Rosamond is cheered up by this, and decides to send out invitations for a dinner party. Of course, all invitations are denied, and Rosamond is still ignorant as to the reason why; she goes to visit her parents, and they tell her the terrible news. When she goes home, she tells her husband that she has heard about everything; she then reiterates that they must go to London, to lessen her suffering. He cannot stand to hear this, and storms out, without taking the time to correct her or explain anything.

0.text: Affery goes to bed. Then she has what she thinks is a dream. She 'dreams' that she goes downstairs and sees Flintwinch talking to himself - no, literally, talking to a double of himself. She totally freaks out and becomes sort of catatonic and paralyzed with fear. The double picks up an iron box and goes out the door. Flintwinch sees Affery on the stairs and pushes her back to the bedroom silently. Then he chokes the living daylights out of her, while shaking her awake. He tells her she's been having a nightmare and if she has another one, he's going to give her a big dose of medicine. You know, the beating-the-crap-out-of-you kind of medicine.

2.text: Affery goes to bed. Then she has what she believes is a dream. She 'dreams' that she goes down the stairs and sees Flintwinch speaking alone - no, really, speaking to a double of himself. Flintwinch sees Affery on the stairs and gently pushes her towards the bedroom. Then he softly submits her to asphyxiation, bringing her back to life. 0.text: In the village, people gather to hear Dinah's preaching. The tavern manager, Mr. Casson, comes outside to see what the commotion is, and he meets a stranger on a horse. He and the stranger have a discussion about Dinah, and Mr. Casson says he believes it is inappropriate for a woman to preach on the village green. As Dinah begins to preach, she draws in the villagers with her soft, loving voice, and the stranger stays to listen to her despite his reservations about a woman preacher. Dinah's sermon tells about the love Jesus has for the poor and encourages the townspeople to give up their sins and do good in the world. The villagers accept her slowly, and by the time she concludes her preaching, many of them are moved to tears

2.text:
In the village, people gather to listen to Dinah preach. The hotelier, Mr. Casson, goes out to see what's going on and encounters a stranger on horseback. They discuss Dinah, and Mr. Casson expresses his concerns about a woman preaching in the village square. As Dinah begins to preach, she attracts the villagers with her soft and loving voice, and the stranger listens in as well, despite his reservations about a female preacher. Dinah's sermon speaks of Jesus' love for the poor and encourages the villagers to abandon their sins and do good in the world. The villagers gradually rally to Dinah, and when she finishes her sermon, many of them are deeply moved to tears.

English translation:

In the village, people gather to listen to Dinah preach. Mr. Casson, the hotelier, steps out to see what's happening and encounters a stranger on horseback. They talk about Dinah, and Mr. Casson shares his worries about a woman preaching in the village square. When Dinah starts preaching, her gentle and loving voice draws the villagers in, and the stranger listens too, despite his reservations about a female preacher. Dinah's sermon is about Jesus' love for the downtrodden and urges the villagers to give up their sins and do good. The villagers gradually warm up to Dinah, and when she finishes her sermon, many of them are deeply moved to tears.

Dinah's message revolves around Jesus' affection for the oppressed, urging the villagers to abandon their sins and do good. Gradually, the villagers draw closer to Dinah, and at the end of her sermon, many are deeply moved and weep.

0.text: Hester has heard that certain influential citizens feel Pearl should be taken from her. Alarmed, Hester sets out with Pearl for Governor Bellingham's mansion to deliver gloves that he ordered. More important, however, Hester plans to plead for the right to keep her daughter. Pearl has been especially dressed for the occasion in an elaborate scarlet dress, embroidered with gold thread. On the way to the governor's mansion, Hester and Pearl are accosted by a group of Puritan children. When they taunt Pearl, she shows a temper as fiery as her appearance, driving the children off with her screams and threats. Reaching the Governor's large, elaborate, stucco frame dwelling, Hester and Pearl are admitted by a bondsman. Inside a heavy oak hall, Hester and Pearl stand before Governor Bellingham's suit of armor. In its curved, polished breastplate, both Hester's scarlet A and Pearl are distorted. Meanwhile, as Hester contemplates her daughter's changed image, a small group of men approaches. Pearl becomes quiet out of curiosity about the men who are coming down the path.

0.text: The men run off to fight, and Roxane collapses over Christian's body. Cyrano leans down and whispers into Christian's ear that he told Roxane the secret, and that she chose Christian. The battle breaks out all around them and Christian closes his eyes, dead. Next to Christian's heart, Roxane finds the farewell letter that Cyrano wrote for Christian to give her. She faints with grief, and Cyrano sends Ragueneau and de Guiche to take her away and protect her. Carbon emerges from the fighting, twice wounded. But the army has returned, and the men will win if they can hold out only a little longer. Cyrano tells Carbon not to worry. Now, he says, he has two deaths to avenge: Christian's and his own. 0.text: The scene opens in Caesar's house. It is a stormy night and Calphurnia has dreamed of Caesar's murder. She asks a servant to instruct an augurer to interpret the signs, and she implores Caesar on her knees to stay at home. The servant returns, advising that Caesar should stay at home, and eventually he agrees, and he will advise Antony to tell the Senators that he is sick. Decius Brutus enters and he gives his interpretation to the omen. The vision concerned Romans dipping their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius says that Calphurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood reviving Rome and the Romans are smiling because they are renewed. Decius goes on to suggest that the Senate will ridicule Caesar for being governed by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitol. Caesar arrives and he welcomes Antony who is suffering the effects of partying the previous night.

2.text:
Scne ouverte  la maison de Caesar. Ce soir, il pleut torrentiellement. Calpurnia a eu un rve de la mort de Caesar. Elle demande  un serviteur d'appeler un augure pour interprter les signes et supplie Caesar de rester  genoux  la maison. Le serviteur revient, lui conseillant de tenir Caesar  la maison, et elle parvient  le convaincre. Il suggre ensuite que Antony informe les Snateurs que Caesar est malade. Decius Brutus entre ensuite et donne son interprtation des prsages. Selon lui, la vision concernait des Romains qui rincaient leurs mains dans le sang qui coulait de la statue de Caesar. Decius explique que le rve de Calpurnia reprsente le sang de Caesar qui renouvellera Rome, et les Romains riant parce qu'ils sont renouvels. Decius continue en disant que le Snat rit de Caesar parce qu'il est gouvern par les rves de sa femme. Caesar change d'avis et se rend au Capitole. Caesar arrive et salut Antony, qui souffre encore des effets du banquet de la nuit prcdente.

Open scene at Caesar's house. It is raining torrentially tonight. Calpurnia had a dream about Caesar's death. She asks a servant to call for an augur to interpret the signs and begs Caesar to stay on his knees at home. The servant returns, advising her to keep Caesar at home, and she manages to convince him. He then suggests that Antony informs the Senators that Caesar is ill. Decius Brutus enters next and gives his interpretation of the omens. According to him, the vision was of Romans washing their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius explains that Calpurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood renewing Rome, and the Romans laughing because they are renewed. Decius continues by saying that the Senate is laughing at Caesar because he is ruled by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Cap

4.text:
At Caesar's house. It's raining heavily tonight. Calpurnia had a dream about Caesar's death. She asks a servant to call for a haruspice to interpret the signs and begs Caesar to stay at home and kneel. The servant returns, advising her to keep Caesar there, and she manages to convince him. He then suggests that Antony informs the Senators that Caesar is ill. Decius Brutus enters next and gives his interpretation of the omens. According to him, the vision was of Romans washing their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius explains that Calpurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood renewing Rome, and the Romans laughing because they are renewed. Decius continues by saying that the Senate is laughing at Caesar because he is ruled by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitole. 6.text: To Caesar. It rains heavily tonight. Calpurnia had dreamed of Caesar's death. She asked a servant to call a haruspice to interpret the signs and to kneel and stay. The servant returns saying that it should be allowed to be and even manages to convince her. He then suggests that the Senators be informed by Antony that Caesar is ill. Decius Brutus enters next and gives his report of the omens. According to him, the vision was of Romans washing their hands in the flowing blood of Caesar's statue. Decius explains that Calpurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood renewing Rome, and the Romans laughing because they are renewed. Decius continues by saying that the Senate laughs at Caesar because he is governed by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitole. Caesar arrives and speaks to Antony, who is still suffering from the effects of the previous banquet. (English translation)

0.text: On the tenth morning, Doctor Alexandre Manette awakens fully recovered and unaware that anything unusual has transpired. Mr. Lorry tactfully conveys to the Doctor what has happened and asks what caused the relapse and how it can be prevented. The Doctor explains that he expected the relapse, which was caused by the revival of certain memories. He believes that the worst is over and doubts that another relapse could occur; if one did, it would most likely result from an intense experience that revived those same memories. Mr. Lorry also questions the wisdom of keeping the shoemaking bench and materials, pointing out that their presence reminds the Doctor of the past that has caused him so much pain. Uneasily agreeing, Doctor Manette requests that Mr. Lorry dispose of the bench and tools without him. Therefore, Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross bury the tools and burn the shoemaking bench after the Doctor leaves to join Lucie and Darnay on their trip.

0.text: The Underground Man wishes that his constant state of inaction were simply because of laziness. That sure would make things easier. And at least then, he says, he could respect himself. Also, at least he would have certainty. If someone asked what he was, the answer would be clear: a lazy person! For example: the Underground Man once knew a guy who was a connoisseur of Lafitte . That was pretty much the guy's only defining feature, but at least he had a defining feature. So he died a happy man. The point is that the Underground Man has no such vocation. If he could pick something to be, he'd pick...mmm...a glutton . A glutton who can appreciate 'everything sublime and beautiful.' The more he thinks about it, the more he realizes that should have been what his life was about: appreciating the sublime and beautiful. He realizes that such a life would probably have meant a lot of crying. Any time someone did anything beautiful or sublime, he would have wept in awe. He also would have gotten fat and red in the nose.

2.text: The Underground Man regrets that his perpetual inactivity is not merely due to laziness. It would make things much simpler for him. At least, he says, he would have respect for himself. Moreover, at least, he would have certainty. If someone asked him what he was, the answer would be clear: a lazy man! For instance: The Underground Man once knew a man who was an expert on Lafitte. That was practically his only distinctive trait, but at least he had one. So, a man can die happily. The point is that The Underground Man has no such calling. If he could choose what he was, he would choose...mmm...a glutton. A glutton who can appreciate 'all that is sublime and beautiful'. The more he thinks about it, the more he realizes that he must have been the meaning of his life: to appreciate the sublime and the beautiful. He realizes that such a life probably would have meant a lot of tears. Every time someone did something beautiful or sublime, he would have cried from admiration. He would have also swelled with pride and blushed from his nose.

A gourmand capable of appreciating 'everything that is sublime and beautiful.' The more I think about it, the more I realize that I should be the reason for my own life: to appreciate the sublime and the beautiful. I realize that such a life would probably have meant a lot of tears. Every time someone did something beautiful or sublime, I would have shed tears of joy. I would have swelled with pride and blushed with shame.

0.text: Coriolanus shows up at the marketplace ready to deliver the big apology. The plebeians, along with Sicinius and Brutus, are waiting for him. First, Menenius reminds everyone that Coriolanus is a big war hero with the scars to prove it. The tribunes decide it's time to pounce and waste no time provoking Coriolanus. Sicinius officially accuses him of acting like a big old tyrant and a traitor, which--big shock--sends Coriolanus into yet another rage. Coriolanus proceeds to insult the tribunes and plebeians, daring them to punish him with exile, death, or torture. Meanwhile, his senator buddies can only stand by and watch this train wreck unfold. Finally, the tribunes declare that Coriolanus is banned from Rome 4EVA. Coriolanus is all 'Oh yeah? I don't think so. You're not banishing me. I'm banishing you!'

2.text: Coriolanus appears at the market, ready for a great reconciliation. The plebeians, accompanied by Sicinius and Brutus, are waiting for his arrival. At first, Menenius reminds everyone that Coriolanus is a great military hero, with scars to prove it. The tribunes think this is the moment to seize the opportunity and confront Coriolanus without delay. Sicinius formally accuses him of being a tyrant and a traitor, which undoubtedly angers Coriolanus once again. Coriolanus then insults the tribunes and the plebeians, threatening them with exile, death, or torture. Meanwhile, his senator friends can only watch helplessly as this disaster unfolds. In the end, the tribunes declare that Coriolanus is expelled from Rome for life. Coriolanus responds: 'Is that so? I don't exclude you; you exclude me!'

4.text:
tribunes and plebeians (in the Roman Assembly): Coriolanus, you are accused of treason and tyranny against the people!

Coriolanus: Is that so? I don't exclude you; you exclude me! (insulting tone) But I'll tell you this: I have never been one to grovel before a mob! I have always relied on my own strength and valor!

tribunes and plebeians: You dare to speak to us in such a manner? You have betrayed the people's trust!

Coriolanus: Trust? I have never asked for your trust! I have only ever served Rome and her interests!

tribunes and plebeians: You are a traitor and a tyrant!

Coriolanus: And you are a pack of ungrateful, whining rabble! I spit on your accusations! (threatening tone) If you persist in this, I swear by the gods, I will crush you all!

tribunes and plebeians: (angrily) We will not be intimidated by you! We will see to it that justice is served!

Coriolanus: (contemptuously) Justice? Your so-called justice is just a tool for your selfish desires! I will not be bound by your petty rules and regulations!

tribunes and plebeians: We will not let you get away with this! We will make sure that the people's voice is heard!

Coriolanus: (mockingly) The people's voice? You speak for the mob, not for the true Romans! I will not be shackled by your ignorance and your fear!

(The scene ends with the tribunes and plebeians becoming more enraged and determined, while Coriolanus stands defiantly, unwilling to back down from his position.)

Translation:

tribunes and plebeians (in the Roman Assembly): Coriolanus, you are charged with treason and tyranny against the people!

Coriolanus: Is that so? I don't exclude you; you exclude me! (insulting tone) But let me tell you this: I have never stooped to beg before a mob! I have always relied on my own strength
