0.text: The Wood-Sawyer Lucie is unsure for one year and three months whether her husband has been alive or dead. She establishes a routine in their new home, and she keeps herself hopeful by setting aside a chair or books for her husband and otherwise behaving as if he lived there, too. Her father informs her that there is a place that she can stand on the sidewalk during certain hours which is overlooked by a window in the prison which her husband may sometimes look out. Lucie faithfully walks back and forth on that sidewalk for two hours each day. Jacques Four has now become a wood-sawyer and has a shack to cut wood near where Lucie walks. He notices that she is there every day, and he mocks her for knowing someone in the prison, pretending to guillotine the whole family with his saw. During December, a crowd of five hundred including Jacques Four and the Vengeance descend on Lucie while she is walking near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her that they will not harm her. Madame Defarge walks by and salutes them. Charles is summoned to appear in court the next day

2.text: (Translation: Lucie Manette is unsure for a year and a half if her husband, Darnay, is alive or dead. She establishes a routine in their new home and remains hopeful, setting aside a chair or books for him and acting as if he were present. Her father informs her of a spot on the pavement where she can wait for hours, overlooking a prison window from which her husband might occasionally look out. Lucie walks two hours a day along this pavement. Jacques Four becomes a woodcutter and owns a cabin for chopping wood near where Lucie walks. He notices her every day and mockingly chops off the heads of her family with his ax. In December, a crowd of five hundred people, including Jacques Four and Sydney Carton, gather around Lucie as she stands near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her that they mean her no harm. Madame Defarge passes by and greets her. Charles Darnay is summoned to appear before the court the following day.)

4.text:
Lucie Manette is uncertain for a year and a half whether her husband, Darnay, is alive or dead. She establishes a routine in their new home and remains hopeful, setting aside a chair or books for him and acting as if he were present. Her father tells her of a spot on the sidewalk where she can wait for hours, overlooking a prison window from which her husband might sometimes look out. Lucie takes a two-hour walk along this sidewalk every day. Jacques Four becomes a woodcutter and owns a cabin for cutting wood near where Lucie walks. He notices her each day and mocks her by chopping off the heads of her family with his ax. In December, a crowd of five hundred people, including Jacques Four and Sydney Carton, gather around Lucie near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her, saying they mean her no harm. Madame Defarge greets her.

Translation:

Lucie Manette est incertaine pendant une anne et demie si son mari, Darnay, est vivant ou mort. Elle tablit une routine dans leur nouvelle demeure et reste esprante, rservant un fauteuil ou des livres pour lui et l'agissant comme s'il tait prsent. Son pre lui apprend d'une place sur la chausse o elle peut attendre des heures, en surplomb d'une fentre de prison  partir de laquelle son mari pourrait parfois regarder. Lucie fait deux heures de promenade par jour le langs de cette chausse. Jacques Four devient un bcheron et possde une cabane pour couper du bois prs de l o Lucie marche. Il la remarque chaque jour et la moque en coupant les ttes de sa famille avec son axe.  dcembre, une foule de cinq cents personnes, dont Jacques Four et Sydney Carton, se rassemblent autour de Lucie prs de la prison. Elle est effraye, mais son pre la rassure en disant qu'ils ne lui font aucun mal. Madame Defarge la salut.

Translation:

Lucie Manette is unsure for a year and a half whether her husband, Darnay, is living or dead. She sets up a routine in their new home

6.text:
Lucie Manette was uncertain for a year and a half whether her husband, Darnay, was alive or dead. She established a routine in their new home and remained hopeful, setting aside a chair or books for him and treating him as if he were present. Her father informed her of a pavement where she could wait for hours in front of a prison window from which her husband might sometimes look out. Lucie spent two hours walking along this pavement every day. Jacques Four becomes a woodcutter and owns a cabin nearby to cut wood. He notices her every day and amuses himself by chopping off the heads of his family with his axe. In December, a crowd of five hundred people, including Jacques Four and Sydney Carton, gather around Lucie near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her, explaining that they do her no harm. Madame Defarge greets her.

Translation:

Lucie Manette s'est mue pendant un an et six mois sur le sort de son mari, Darnay. Elle a instaur une routine dans leur nouvelle demeure et a reste esprante, en rservant une chaise ou des livres pour lui et le traitant comme s'il tait prsent. Son pre lui a appris d'une pierre de trottoir sur laquelle elle pouvait attendre pendant des heures, devant une fentre de prison o son mari pourrait parfois regarder. Lucie passe deux heures chaque jour le long de ce trottoir  pied. Jacques Four devient un bcheron et possde une cabane pour couper du bois  proximit. Il la remarque chaque jour et se amuse en enlevant les ttes de sa famille avec son bche.  dcembre, une foule de cinq cents personnes, dont Jacques Four et Sydney Carton, se rassemblent autour de Lucie prs de la prison. Elle est effraye, mais son pre la rassure en expliquant qu'ils ne lui font aucun mal. Madame Defarge la salut.

0.text: In the year 1640, the Hall of the Hotel de Bourgogne--a large, crowded Parisian theater--buzzes with activity in the minutes before a performance of the play La Clorise. People mill about and converse, divided according to their social class. A citizen guides his son through the room, impressing upon him the intellectual magnitude of the performance. A thief moves through the crowd, stealing handkerchiefs and purses. A group of pages runs about firing peashooters at one another. Two elegant marquises, with swords strapped to their waists, tread through the crowd, aloof and condescending. The lamps are lit, and the crowd cheers, knowing the performance will commence soon

2.text: Year 1640, the Burgundy Room at the Htel - a grand and bustling Parisian theater - echoes with activity in the final moments before the performance of the play Cloris. People scatter and converse, according to their social class. A citizen leads his son through the room, impressing upon him the intellectual importance of the performance. A thief slips through the crowd, stealing handkerchiefs and wallets. A group of pages weave their way through the crowd, drawing pistols on one another. Two elegant marquises, with swords hanging from their belts, cross the crowd, distant and disdainful. The lamps are lit, and the crowd applauds, knowing that the performance is about to begin.

4.text: Year 1640, the Bourgogne Hall at the Hotel, a vast and bustling Parisian theatre room, echoes with activity in the last moments before the performance of the play Cloris. People scatter and engage in conversations, according to their social class. A citizen leads his son through the room, emphasizing the intellectual importance of the performance. A thief slips through the crowd, stealing cigar boxes and wallets. A group of pages weave through the crowd, brandishing pistols at each other. Two elegant marquises, with swords hanging from their belts, cross the crowd, distant and contemptuous. The lamps are lit, and the crowd applauds, knowing that the performance is about to begin.

0.text: The setting shifts to the outside battlements of the castle at Elsinore. As earlier planned, Hamlet arrives with Horatio and Marcellus, just before midnight in order to watch for the Ghost. While they are speaking to one another, a flourish of trumpets and canon fire is heard in the distance. Hamlet explains in disgust that this is a sign that the new King, his uncle and stepfather, is engaged in his customary drunken revelry. Suddenly the ghost appears. Hamlet addresses the apparition as 'King, father; royal Dane' and implores it to reveal the reason for its nocturnal wanderings. The ghost simply beckons Hamlet to follow it to another place. Horatio and Marcellus beg Hamlet not to obey the ghost, fearing it would be dangerous and could even lead to his death; but Hamlet ignores his friends' warnings, breaks away from them when they try to physically restrain him, and follows the Ghost. Horatio and Marcellus are convinced that 'something is rotten in the state of Denmark' and decide to follow Hamlet.

2.text: Outside the outer ramparts of Elsinore Castle, earlier plans had Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcellus arriving around midnight to keep watch for the ghost. As they spoke among themselves, they heard trumpet blasts and gunshots in the distance. Hamlet is startled and disgusted, explaining that this is a sign that his uncle and father-in-law, the new King, is once again indulging in his usual drunken revelries. Suddenly, the ghostly apparition appears. Hamlet addresses it as 'King, father; Danish royal king,' and begs it to reveal the reason for its nightly wanderings. The apparition only signals for Hamlet to follow it elsewhere. Horatio and Marcellus plead with Hamlet not to obey the ghost, fearing it could be dangerous and even lead to his death; but Hamlet ignores their warnings, breaks free of their grasp when they try to physically restrain him, and follows the Ghost. Horatio and Marcellus are convinced that 'there is something strange in Denmark,' and decide to follow as well.

4.text: Before the external ramparts of Elsinore, Hamlet, Horace, and Marcellus were to arrive around midnight for their external watch at the walls, waiting for the specter. In their conversation, they heard trumpet fanfares and gunshots on the horizon. Hamlet recoiled, explaining that this meant his uncle and father-in-law, the new King, were once again engaging in their usual drunken revelries. Suddenly, the apparition appeared. Hamlet called out to it, 'King, father; Danish king,' and asked it to reveal the reasons for its nightly wanderings. The apparition only indicated to Hamlet to follow it elsewhere. Horace and Marcellus begged Hamlet not to listen to the specter's call, fearing it could be dangerous and even lead to his death; but Hamlet disregarded their warnings, breaking free of their grasp when they tried to physically restrain him, and followed the Ghost. Convinced that 'there is something amiss in Denmark,' Horace and Marcellus decided to follow him as well.

Hamlet cried out: 'King, father; Danish king,' and begged for reasons for his nocturnal wanderings. The apparition only replied by indicating that he should follow it elsewhere. Horace and Marcellus took Hamlet seriously, urging him not to answer the call of the specter, fearfully worried that it could be dangerous and even lead to his death; but Hamlet ignored their warning, breaking free of their grasp when they tried to physically restrain him, and followed the Apparition. Convinced that 'something was amiss in Denmark', Horace and Marcellus decided to follow him as well.

Convinced that 'something was amiss in Denmark', Horace and Marcellus decided to follow him as well.

50.text:
To fight against a sea of suffering,
And, on the contrary, to put an end to it : to die : to sleep;
Nothing more; and by this death, to take leave
Of pains and thousands of natural shocks
That flesh inherits: it is a consumption
We shall see again. To die, to sleep;
To sleep, perhaps to dream: ah, that is the crucial point;
For in the sleep of death what dreams will come
When we have torn off this garment of flesh,
We shall have rest: it is esteem
That makes calamity a long life;
For who could bear the blows and insults of time,
The tyranny of the oppressor, the insolence of the great,
The pains of unrequited love, the slowness of the law,
The insolence of authority and the contempt
The ungrateful inflict on us,
When it might have put an end to all this
With a simple dagger? Who could bear the burdens,
Complain and grumble under a heavy life,
If it were not for the fear of something after death,
Of an unknown land from which no one returns,
Which confuses our will and makes us endure
What we wanted to flee from, what we do not know?
Thus conscience weakens all;
And the true color of resolution
Is covered by the pale fear of thought,
And great enterprises and projects
Lose their name of action.

65.text:
To fight against a sea of pains,
And, on the contrary, put an end to them: to die: to sleep;
Nothing more; and through this death, take leave
Of pains and the thousands of natural shocks that the flesh inherits:
It is a consumption
To which we shall all be subjected. To die, to sleep;
To sleep, perhaps to dream: ah, that is the great lot;
For in the sleep of death what dreams will come
When we have laid down this heavy shell of flesh,
Makes us think: it is respect
That makes the calamitous long life a thing to fear;
For who would bear the scourges and contempt of time,
The insolence of the oppressor, the insults of the arrogant,
The pains of scorned love, the delay of the law,
The insolence of power and the contempt of merited rewards,
When itself could put an end to its sufferings
With a simple knife? Who would carry the burdens,
To suffer and sweat under a heavy life,
Save the fear of something after death,
The unexplored country from which no one returns,
Which awakens the will and makes us endure
These evils that we rather flee from to other unknowns?
Thus conscience makes cowards of us all;
And thus, native resolution
Is covered with a pale cast of thought,
And great enterprises and projects
Are thrown off their course,
And lose their name of action.

80.text:
To die, to sleep;
But to sleep, perhaps to dream: ah, there's the rub;
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come,
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause: there's the respect that makes
Calamity of so long life;
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
The pangs of despised love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office and the spurns
That patient merit of the unworthy takes,
When we ourselves might bear the whip and the cross,
And the pangs of despised love, the law's delay,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscovered country from whose bourn
No traveller returns, puzzles the will
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all;
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pitch and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action.-- Shakespeare, Hamlet.

100.text:
To die, to sleep;
But to sleep, perchance to dream: ay, there's the rub;
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come,
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause: there's the respect
That makes calamity of so long life;
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumacy,
The pangs of despised love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office and the spurns
That patient merit of th' unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin? Who would fardels bear,
To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscovered country from whose bourn
No traveller returns, puzzles the will
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all;
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pitch and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action.-- Shakespeare, Hamlet.

0.text: During a storm, Mr. and Mrs. Bumble travel to a sordid section of town near a swollen river to meet Monks in a decaying building. While Mr. Bumble shivers in fear, Mrs. Bumble coolly bargains with Monks. They settle on a price of twenty-five pounds for her information. Mrs. Bumble relates how Old Sally robbed Oliver's mother. Mrs. Bumble says she discovered a ragged pawnbroker's receipt in Old Sally's dead hands and that she redeemed it for the gold locket, which she then hands to Monks. Inside, he finds a wedding ring and two locks of hair. The name 'Agnes' is engraved on the ring, along with a blank for the surname. Monks ties the locket to a weight and drops it into the river

2.text:
During a tempest, Mr. and Mrs. Bumble go to a part of the city near a swollen river to meet the Monks in a ruined building. Mr. Bumble is terrified, but Mrs. Bumble stays calm and negotiates peacefully with the Monks. They reach an agreement on a price of twenty-five pounds for the information. Mrs. Bumble tells how Old Sally had stolen a jewel from Oliver's mother. She reveals that she had found a pawnshop receipt in Old Sally's dead hands and exchanged it for the collar, which she then gave to the Monks. Upon examination, they discover a marriage ring and two hairs. The inscription on the ring reads 'Agnes,' with a space for a surname. The Monks attach the chain to a weight and throw it into the river.

6.text:
During a tempest, Mr. and Mrs. Bumble go to a part of the city near a swollen river to meet the Monks in a ruins. Mr. Bumble is terrified, but Mrs. Bumble remains calm and negotiates peacefully with the Monks. They reach an agreement for a price of twenty-five pounds for the information. Mrs. Bumble tells them how Sally Oldwoman had stolen a jewel from Oliver's mother. She reveals that she had found a sales receipt in Sally Oldwoman's dead hands and exchanged it for the collar, which she then gave to them. During the examination, they discover a wedding ring and two hairs. The inscription on the ring reads 'Agnes,' followed by a space for a family name. The Monks attach a weight to the chain and throw it into the river.

Translated from French:

Durant une tempte, M. et Mme. Bumble se rendent dans une partie de la ville prs d'un fleuve gonfl pour rencontrer les Moines dans une ruine. M. Bumble est effray, mais Mme. Bumble reste apaise et ngocie tranquillement avec les Moines. Ils concluent un accord pour un prix de vingt-cinq livres pour l'information. Mme. Bumble leur raconte comment Sally Oldwoman avait vol un joyau  la mre d'Oliver. Elle rvle qu'elle avait trouv un bon de vente dans les mains mortes de Sally Oldwoman et l'a chang contre la collier, qu'elle leur a ensuite donn. Pendant l'examen, ils dcouvrent un anneau de mariage et deux cheveux. L'inscription sur l'anneau lit 'Agnes,' suivi d'un espace pour un nom de famille. Les Moines attachent un poids  la chane et la jettent dans le fleuve.

0.text: Diomedes sends his servant with a message to Cressida about how he just beat down her ex-boyfriend. He also sends along Troilus's horse as proof that he's now Cressida's 'knight' in shining armor. Agamemnon appears and lists all the Greeks who have been killed, including Achilles' lover, Patroclus. He and Diomedes run off to get reinforcements while Nestor shows up to deliver the bad news about Patroclus. Then he tells us that Hector is running around the battlefield mowing down Greek warriors like a one-man army. Ulysses runs up and says that Achilles is 'weeping, cursing' and 'vowing vengeance' for Patroclus' death. We find out that Achilles and his gang of hooligan 'Myrmidons' are out for Hector's blood. Ajax runs in looking to kill Troilus.

2.text: Diomede sends his servant to Cressida with news of his victory over his former lover. He presents her with Troilus' horse as a token that he is now her 'knight' of shining steel. Agamemnon appears and announces the deaths of all the Greeks, among them Patroclus, lover of Achilles. Agamemnon and Diomede leave to gather reinforcements, while Nestor arrives to bring us the sad news about Patroclus. Then, Nestor informs us that Hector is roaming the battlefield, killing Greek soldiers one by one. Ulysses arrives, exhausted, to inform us that Achilles is grieving, swearing and blaspheming over Patroclus' death. We learn that Achilles and his Myrmidon companions are determined to avenge Patroclus' death by seeking out Hector. Ajax becomes enraged and enters, resolved to kill Troilus.

0.text: On Christmas morning Jim wakes up to see the men coming in from their morning chores. They all shout 'Merry Christmas' to each other. Grandfather says particularly long prayers that morning and reads aloud from the Bible. He thanks God for Christmas. Narrator-Jim remarks that Grandfather had a special talent for saying prayers. They have waffles and sausage for breakfast. Jake tells them that the Shimerdas were happy with their presents, even Ambrosch. That afternoon Jake and Jim play marbles while Otto writes a letter to his mother, as he does every Christmas. At 4pm Mr. Shimerda shows up with his rabbit-skin winter gear. He's there to thank them for everything they've done for his family. He seems to be very content, though it's only a break from his constant sadness. At 9pm, he leaves to go home. As he departs, he makes the sign of the cross over Grandmother and tells her that she's a good woman. He adds that the prayers of all good people are good.

2.text: Christmas Morning, Jim wakes up early and sees the men returning from their morning chores. They all greet each other with 'Merry Christmas.' Father, who had particularly pronounced his prayers that morning, reads the Bible aloud. He thanks God for Christmas. Jim notices that Father had a special gift for praying. They have waffles and sausages for breakfast. Jake announces that the Shimerdas were happy with their gifts, even Ambrosch. In the afternoon, Jake and Jim play dice. Otto writes a letter to his mother, as he does every year. At 4 a.m., Mr. Shimerda arrives with his winter fur equipment to thank them for what they had done for his family. He seems happy, although it is only a pause in his constant sadness. At 9 p.m., he leaves to go back home. As he leaves, he makes the sign of the cross before Grandmother and tells her she is a good woman. He adds that the prayers of all good people are beneficial.

0.text: Isabel is doing a lot of thinking. We learn about her thoughts on her marriage to Osmond and Lord Warburton's pursuit of Pansy. Isabel wonders if she gave a false image of herself to Osmond when they first got involved. Isabel feels certain that Osmond hates her, because she doesn't have a sense of 'tradition.' Well, of course not - isn't her originality the very thing that people love about her? Not only does he hate her opinions and beliefs, he also takes offense to the whole manner with which she conducts her life. We discover the grim truth behind their relationship: Osmond has gradually gained total control of Isabel, who was once so proud and independent. Isabel and Osmond have barely been speaking to one another. Isabel knows that Osmond is upset and jealous about Ralph's stay in Rome. Isabel has not told Ralph how miserable her life is. She thinks that it is better for him to think that he was wrong all along, although, in fact, he was all too right. Isabel stays up until four in the morning thinking things over. She can't shake off the alarming image of Madame Merle and Osmond in cahoots.

In fact, he hates not only her opinions and beliefs but is also offended by the entire tone of how she lives her life. We discover the terrible truth behind their relationship: Osmond has gradually gained complete control over Isabel, who was once so proud and independent. She thinks it's better for him to believe he was reasonable all along, even if that's not the case. Isabel thinks about this until four in the morning. She cannot get rid of the alarming image of Madame Merle and Osmond in collusion.

Isabelle had told Ralph nothing about her situation. She found comfort in his calmness, no matter the context.

Translation (English):

Isabelle had deeply immersed herself in her marriage with Osmond and in her own image. She had carefully created false versions of herself that she had shown to Osmond during their engagement. Believing that he hated her because he hated her cherished traditions, in reality, he hated not only her vanity but also her thoughts and ideas. The truth about their relationship came to light: Osmond was beginning to dominate Isabelle more and more, who had been an independent and vivacious woman before. Isabelle and Osmond seemed to no longer communicate with each other these days. Isabelle was aware of Osmond's intolerance and jealousy towards Ralph's hospitalities in Rome. Isabelle had told Ralph nothing about her situation. She found comfort in his calmness, regardless of the context.

0.text: The witches again meet at an open place, this time with Hecate, the goddess of witches, who looks pretty angry. Hecate lays into the weird sisters in a lengthy, rhyming speech that sounds a bit like a nursery rhyme. She's super irritated that they were meddling in the affairs of Macbeth without consulting her first, as she could've done a better job. Also, she points out, Macbeth isn't devoted to them, only to himself. But, fine, Hecate will clean up this mess. She tells them to all meet in the morning, when Macbeth will come to know his destiny, whatever that means. Then there's a catchy witch song and dance, and everyone exits after Hecate. FYI: Some literary critics believe that these scene is way too hokey to be Shakespeare's work, so it must have been added to the play some time between the time the play was first written and its publication in the first folio , which was after Shakespeare's death . A fellow playwright, Thomas Middleton, may have written the snazzy songs in this scene.

2.text:
First Folio, which took place after Shakespeare's death. It is suspected that another playwright, Thomas Middleton, wrote the scene's songs.

(The witches gather once more in an open place, now accompanied by Hecate, the goddess of witches, who appears very angry. Hecate scolds the strange sisters with a long diatribe in rhyme that resembles a nursery rhyme. She is angry because they interfered in Macbeth's affairs without consulting her initially, which she could have handled more effectively. Moreover, she asserts, Macbeth is not faithful to them but only to himself. However, Hecate intends to rectify this situation. She orders them to gather every morning when Macbeth learns his fate, which implies something significant. Following this, an enchanting song and a dance of witches ensue, and they leave after Hecate.)

0.text: Elsewhere in the castle, Lady Macbeth expresses despair and sends a servant to fetch her husband. Macbeth enters and tells his wife that he too is discontented, saying that his mind is 'full of scorpions'. He feels that the business that they began by killing Duncan is not yet complete because there are still threats to the throne that must be eliminated. Macbeth tells his wife that he has planned 'a deed of dreadful note' for Banquo and Fleance and urges her to be jovial and kind to Banquo during the evening's feast, in order to lure their next victim into a false sense of security

0.text: Lydgate was indifferent to the voting on the question of chaplaincy at the hospital. Having met Farebrother and been drawn to him, he faces a dilemma. His personal preference is for Farebrother, who has a humane touch and who has been serving as chaplain all along without pay. Now that the post is an earned one, it seems unfair to deprive him. On the other hand, Bulstrode is Lydgates main backer in the town, where he anticipates serious oppositions to his plans for medical reform. Lydgate, therefore, attends the meeting in a confused state. There is heated discussion much of personal, among the members who have earlier assembled. Lydgate comes in last and finds them equally divided. Ultimately, his casting vote is decided by his smarting ego. Mr. Wrench, an old style medical practitioner, declares that it is well known that Lydgate will vote will Bulstrode. Incensed, Lydgate does just that. So Mr. Tyke becomes the hospital chaplain. Farebrother meanwhile, continues to meet Lydgate with the same friendliness as before. But his skepticism and tolerant attitude dont impress Lydgate favorably.

0.text: The next morning, Ellen woke Linton early and took him over to Wuthering Heights, promising dishonestly that it was only for a little while. Linton was surprised to hear he had a father, since Isabella had never spoken of Heathcliff. When they arrived, Heathcliff and Joseph expressed their contempt for the delicate boy. Heathcliff told Linton that his mother was a 'wicked slut' because she did not tell Linton about his father. Ellen asked Heathcliff to be kind to the boy, and he said that he would indeed have him carefully tended, mostly because Linton was heir to the Grange, so he wanted him to live at least until Edgar was dead and he inherited. So when Linton refused to eat the homely oatmeal Joseph offered him, Heathcliff ordered that his son be given tea and boiled milk instead. When Ellen left, Linton begged her not to leave him there

0.text: Book II, Chapter 6 Carrie accompanies the Gormers to one of their new houses and while there meets George Dorset while taking a walk. He pleads with her to give him some proof of his wife's infidelities, implying that he wants to divorce her and marry Lily instead. Lily becomes afraid and runs away from him, telling him she cannot help. When she returns to the Gormer house, Mrs. Gormer informs her that Bertha Dorset had been there for a visit. Lily head back to the city and finds a place in a hotel, paying more for her rent than she can afford. She is soon visited by Mr. Dorset who implores her to help him out of his situation, but Lily refuses to reveal anything. She then goes to visit Carrie Fisher and finds Rosedale in Carrie's house, most likely invited there so he and Lily could meet. After the dinner Carrie talks with Lily alone, and tells her that in order to defeat Bertha Dorset, Lily will have to either marry Mr. Dorset or marry someone else.

0.text: The King and Laertes are discussing the crime that has been committed by Hamlet when a messenger arrives bearing a letter announcing Hamlet's impending return. Claudius requests that Laertes help to kill the Prince. Laertes, seeking to avenge his father is all too willing. He plans to poison his sword and use it to slay Hamlet. The king agrees to this plan and says that if it fails, he will give Hamlet a poisoned cup of wine. The Queen enters and announces that Ophelia has drowned. Laertes laments her death and leaves. Claudius tells Gertrude that he has been calming Laertes and that they should follow lest this news cause his temper to flare again.

2.text: They discuss Hamlet's crime with the King when a messenger arrives with news of his approaching arrival. Claudius asks Laertes to assist him in killing the Prince. Laertes, seeking revenge for his father, has no hesitation. He poisons his sword and intends to use it against Hamlet. The king agrees to the plan and adds that if it fails, Hamlet will be given a poisoned cup. The Queen enters and announces Ophelia's drowning. Laertes grieves for her death and departs. Claudius informs Gertrude that he has placated Laertes and they must follow, as this news might rekindle his anger.

The King accepts the plan and adds that if it fails, Hamlet will receive a poisoned chalice. The Queen enters and announces Ophelia's death. Laertes grieves for her and leaves. Claudius informs Gertrude that he has mollified Laertes and they must follow, as this news may awaken her anger.

Laertes mourns for her and departs. Claudius apprises Gertrude that he has soothed Laertes and they must proceed, as this intelligence might provoke her.

0.text: The old neighbor has problems of her own. She's a beggar and a thief, but for now, she's Jimmie's only option. She dispatches Jimmie to buy her a can of beer. Unfortunately, Jimmie's father intercepts him and steals the beer. He can't cope with the 'livin hell' at home either. Jimmie hangs out before returning to the apartment. Adam infers that she is recovering from Arthur. He remains optimistic. The narrator reflects on Adam's love for Hetty. On the one hand, he falls in love with her based on what she shows, unaware of her true nature. On the other hand, the narrator supposes that Adam's love stems from his strength rather than his weakness, for love is a wonderful symphony awakened by beauty, and Hetty touches the deepest part of Adam. Adam's professional career prospers, and he can consider a wife. M. Burge proposes a partnership, and with two jobs, he can buy a house.

0.text: Lydia and Wickham are found and, as expected, they are not married. Wickham, however, has agreed to marry her on the stipulation that his debts are cleared and he is given a stipend of one hundred pounds a year. Mr. Bennet agrees to the offer, but suspects that a much greater amount must have been passed on by Mr. Gardiner to maneuver Wickham to yield. Mrs. Bennet, upon hearing that Lydia is to be married, forgets the disgraceful state of affairs under which the marriage is coming to a pass. She enthusiastically proceeds to make arrangements for a wedding and to convey the glad tidings in the neighborhood.

2.text:

However, Wickham agreed to marry her, on condition that his debts be settled and he received an annual pension of one hundred pounds. Mr. Bennet accepts this offer, but suspects that a larger sum of money had been transferred by Mr. Gardiner to push Wickham into conceding. Mrs. Bennet, learning that Lydia was to be married, forgets the shameful circumstances surrounding this union. They then make preparations for a wedding and announce the happy news in the neighborhood.

0.text: Babbitt is elected as an official delegate to the annual convention for the State Association of Real Estate Boards. When Cecil Rountree, the chairman of the convention program-committee, asks Babbitt to write a paper espousing his views about real estate for the convention, Babbitt eagerly accepts the honor. However, he encounters trouble in writing the paper because he becomes mired in concerns about 'Style, Order, and other mysteries. ' Finally, he dispenses with all of these concerns and produces a concise, clear presentation on his thoughts about the real estate business. Babbitt reads his paper before the convention and is instantly hailed as the equal of Cecil Rountree, who is known as a 'diplomat of business.' Babbitt revels in his newfound respect and decides not to return home right away. He remains behind to drink, smoke, attend a burlesque show, and visit a brothel with some of the other delegates. Afterwards, Babbitt never tells anyone about that evening. When he returns to Zenith, it is business as usual.

0.text: The Lilliputian emperor is pleased that Gulliver is friendly and cooperative, so he rewards him with some court diversions. The diversions, however, prove to be quite different than one might expect. It is the Lilliputian court custom that men seeking political office demonstrate their agility in rope dancing, among other things. How long and how skillfully a candidate can dance upon a rope determines his tenure in office. Of the candidates, two are particularly adept: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other diversions include noblemen competing for official favor by crawling under or leaping over a stick, a feat for which they are then rewarded with various colored threads. Gulliver also reviews the Emperor's troops; he stands, legs apart, while the tiny men march through. As a result of Gulliver's cooperation, a pact between Gulliver and the Emperor is agreed on. Gulliver is granted limited freedom on certain conditions. In return for abiding by the conditions, he will receive food sufficient for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the articles in proper form, and the Emperor frees him.

2.text:
The little emperor of Lilliput is pleased that Gulliver is friendly and cooperative, so he offers him some entertainments from his entourage. However, these entertainments turn out to be quite different from what one might expect. The custom of the emperor of Lilliput's entourage is that men seeking political positions demonstrate their agility in a dance on a rope, among other things. The length and control with which a candidate dances on a rope determine his duration. Among the candidates, two are particularly skillful: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other entertainments consist of the nobles competing for official favors by passing under or jumping over a staff, for which they are rewarded with threads of various colors. Gulliver also examines the emperor's troops; he stands with his legs apart while the little men pass through. With Gulliver's help, a treaty is concluded between Gulliver and the emperor. Gulliver receives limited freedoms under certain conditions. In exchange for observing these conditions, he will receive enough food for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the articles appropriately, and the emperor releases him.

The length and dexterity with which a candidate dances on a rope determine his tenure. Among the candidates, two are exceptionally skilled: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other entertainments involve the nobles competing for official favors by passing under or jumping over a staff, for which they are rewarded with threads of various colors. Gulliver also inspects the emperor's troops; he stands with his legs apart while the little men pass through. With Gulliver's assistance, a treaty is concluded between Gulliver and the emperor. 0.text: The Mail On a Friday night in late November of 1775, a mail coach wends its way from London to Dover. The journey proves so treacherous that the three passengers must dismount from the carriage and hike alongside it as it climbs a steep hill. From out of the great mists, a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak to Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react warily, fearing that they have come upon a highwayman or robber. Mr. Lorry, however, recognizes the messenger's voice as that of Jerry Cruncher, the odd-job man at Tellson's, and accepts his message. The note that Jerry passes him reads: 'Wait at Dover for Mam'selle. Lorry instructs Jerry to return to Tellson's with this reply: 'Recalled to Life. Confused and troubled by the 'blazing strange message,' Jerry rides on to deliver it

2.text: A Friday evening in late November of 1775, a postchaise departs from London for Dover. The journey proves to be so dangerous that the three passengers are forced to get down and walk beside the carriage as it climbs a steep hill. In the thick fog, a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak with Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react with caution, fearing they have encountered a bailiff or a thief. However, Mr. Lorry recognizes the messenger's voice as that of Jerry Cruncher, the errand boy of Tellson's Bank, and accepts his message. The note that Jerry hands him reads: 'Wait for her at Dover.' Lorry orders Jerry to return to Tellson's Bank with this response: 'Recalled to life.' Surprised and concerned about the 'mysterious burning message,' Jerry continues on his way to deliver the response.

A Friday evening in late November 1775, a postchaise departs from London for Dover. The journey is dangerous, forcing the three passengers to disembark and walk when the carriage climbs steep hills. In the thick fog, a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak with Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The passengers react with caution, fearing an encounter with a bailiff or a thief. However, Mr. Lorry recognizes the voice of the horseman as that of Jerry Crunch, the little servant of Tellson's Bank, and grants an audience. The note that Jerry presents reads: 'Wait for her at Dover.' Mr. Lorry orders Jerry to return to Tellson's Bank with this response: 'Recalled to life.' Surprised and anxious due to this 'mysterious and inflammatory' message, Jerry continues his journey to complete his delivery.

In English:

On a Friday evening towards the end of November 1775, a postchaise sets off from London for Dover. The journey is perilous, compelling the three passengers to alight and walk when the carriage ascends steep hills. In the dense fog, a messenger on horseback emerges and requests to speak with Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The passengers respond warily, apprehensive of an encounter with a sheriff or a thief. Nevertheless, Mr. Lorry recognizes the rider's voice as that of Jerry Crunch, the small servant of Tellson's Bank, and grants an audience. The note Jerry produces reads: 'Wait for her at Dover.' Mr. Lorry instructs Jerry to return to Tellson's Bank with this reply: 'Recalled to life.' Surprised and concerned due to this 'mysterious and inflammatory' message, Jerry resumes his journey to finish his errand.

40.text:
Friday evening at the end of November 1775, a postchaise left London for Dover. The journey was dangerous, forcing the three passengers to disembark and walk when the vehicle climbed steep hills. In the dense fog, a messenger on horseback appeared and asked to speak with Jarvis Lorry from Tellson Bank. The travelers were anxious, fearing an encounter with a bailiff or a thief. However, Mr. Lorry recognized the voice of Jerry Crunch, the little servant of Tellson Bank, and granted an audience. The note Jerry held contained the message: 'Wait for her at Dover.' Mr. Lorry had ordered Jerry to return to Tellson Bank with this response: 'Recalled to life.' Jerry's sudden and ominous disappearance with this 'mysterious and provocative message' was surprising.

English translation:

On a Friday evening in late November 1775, a postchaise departed from London for Dover. The journey was perilous, compelling the three passengers to alight and walk when the vehicle ascended steep hills. In the thick fog, a messenger on horseback emerged and requested to speak with Jarvis Lorry from Tellson Bank. The passengers were apprehensive, anticipating an encounter with a sheriff or a thief. Nevertheless, Mr. Lorry identified the voice of Jerry Crunch, Tellson Bank's small servant, and granted an audience. The note Jerry clutched read: 'Wait for her at Dover.' Mr. Lorry had instructed Jerry to convey this response back to Tellson Bank: 'Summoned back to life.' Jerry's abrupt and enigmatic departure with this 'mysterious and intriguing message' was intriguing.

0.text: The Governess and Miles, alone at last, speak cagily about Miles's explorations of the grounds over the past day or so, when he's been left to his own devices. Finally, it's time to get everything out in the open. The Governess insists that she's only there to help Miles and to be with him - and he sees that she wants him to tell her everything. As he prepares to confess, she sees for the first time that he's afraid - of her. Miles nervously tells the Governess that he'll tell her anything, but not just now; he says he has to go see Luke . Before she lets him go, the Governess just asks him one thing: did he take the letter she left in the hall yesterday?

The governor and Miles are finally alone, and they timidly discuss his explorations in the gardens during the last days when he had been freed from the rules. At last, it's time to lay all the cards on the table. The governor insists to him that she is there to help him and to be with him - and he sees that she wants him to tell all. Just as he is about to confess, the governor sees for the first time that he is afraid - of her. Miles repeats to the governor that he would tell her everything, but not yet; he says that he must see Luke first. Before letting him go, the governor asks him just one thing: did he take the letter she had left in the hallway yesterday?

0.text: Spring arrives, and Gray Beaver finishes the journey. White Fang is one year old, and next to Lip-lip, he is the largest yearling. He continues to have his battles with other dogs. When he fights with Baseek over a piece of shinbone, White Fang rips Baseeks right ear and wounds him on the shoulder. Baseek, old and weak, gives up. In mid-summer, White Fang encounters Kiche, who has now forgotten him and has had a new litter. She hovers protectively around her litter, trying to drive White Fang away. When White Fang is three years old, there is a great famine in the land. Only the strong will survive, for the Indians eat the weaker dogs. The Indians also eat the soft-tanned leather of their moccasins and mittens to fill their stomachs. White Fang escapes into the forest to hunt on his own, at times robbing rabbit snares and at times capturing small game, like squirrels and woodmice. At the end of the famine, White Fang meets Lip-lip, with whom he fights until Lip-lip is killed. He then returns to the village and is received warmly and given plenty of fish.

2.text:
Arrival of spring, and Gray Beaver completes his journey. Blanc-Mange is one year old, and next to Lip-lip, he is the largest young animal. He continues to quarrel with other dogs. When he quarrels with Baseek over a big bone, Blanc-Mange tears a part of Baseek's left ear and injures his shoulder. Baseek, old and weakened, withdraws. In the middle of summer, Blanc-Mange encounters Kiche, who has forgotten about him and has had a new litter. She defends aggressively around her litter, trying to chase Blanc-Mange away. When Blanc-Mange is three years old, there is a great famine in the land. Only the strong survive, as the Indians consume the weaker dogs. The Indians also consume the soft skin of their moccasins and gloves to fill their stomachs. Blanc-Mange flees into the forest to hunt alone, sometimes stealing rabbit traps and sometimes taking small game, such as squirrels and forest mice. At the end of the famine, Blanc-Mange encounters Lip-lip, with whom he fights until Lip-lip is killed. He returns to the village and is warmly welcomed and receives many fish.

0.text: It is a cold, wet November afternoon when the novel opens at Gateshead, the home of Jane Eyre's relatives, the Reeds. Jane and the Reed children, Eliza, John, and Georgiana sit in the drawing room. Jane's aunt is angry with her, purposely excluding her from the rest of the family, so Jane sits alone in a window seat, reading Bewick's History of British Birds. As she quietly reads, her cousin John torments her, reminding her of her precarious position within the household. As orphaned niece of Mrs. Reed, she should not be allowed to live with gentlemen's children. John throws a book at Jane and she calls him a 'murderer' and 'slave-driver.' The two children fight, and Jane is blamed for the quarrel. As punishment, she is banished to the red-room.

0.text: Cedric is in his home, Rotherwood, impatiently waiting for his servants to come home. He is also displeased that his ward Rowena is late for supper. His thoughts are interrupted by the blast of a horn. Then the gatekeeper announces that Prior Aymer of the Abbey of Jorvaulx, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, and a small party of men are on their way to the royal tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouche and want to lodge at Rotherwood for the night. Cedric does not want to entertain these Normans, but his Saxon pride demands that they be offered hospitality; however, he clings to his dignity by refusing to go out to welcome them. Only when they come to him in his hall does Cedric reluctantly welcome them. Cedric counsels Rowena against appearing before the guests. He does not trust the Knight Templar and does not want anything to interfere with his plans to marry Rowena off to the right gentleman. She, however, is keen to hear the latest news from the Holy Land from the Palmer, since she is in love with Ivanhoe, whom she thinks is still fighting in the Crusades.

0.text: The first thing Adam notices on entering the courtroom is Hetty herself. To Adam she is still beautiful; to less prejudiced eyes she appears hard and worn. Two witnesses give testimony. One says that Hetty had borne the baby in her house and had then run off with it the following day. The other reports finding the dead baby lying half-buried in a small grove and adds that when he had returned to the spot with a constable, they found Hetty sitting there in a state of shock. The case is clear and the verdict of guilty is quickly pronounced. When the judge assigns the death sentence, Hetty shrieks and faints, and is carried from the courtroom.

0.text: When Emma calls for Harriet at the Abbey Farm, the excited girl tells Emma that she has visited with Martin's mother and two sisters. On the way home, Emma decides to stop at the Westons and is disappointed to find they are not home. As she turns to leave, the Westons arrive in their carriage. They inform Emma that Frank Churchill will be arriving the next day and staying for a fortnight. They assure Emma that they will bring Frank to Hartfield. The next day Mr. Weston and Frank call at Woodhouse. Emma finds Frank to be a very good-looking gentleman of well-bred manners; she is also impressed by his lively spirit. He praises Mrs. Weston for her pretty looks and elegant manners. Emma immediately likes Frank and imaginatively concludes that Frank also has an interest in her. She barely notices that he plans to call on Jane Fairfax next since he already knows her.

2.text: When Emma calls for Harriet at Mr. Knightley's farm, the excited girl responds to Emma that she had visited Mrs. and the two sisters of Mr. Knightley. On their way back, Emma decides to stop at the Westons, but is disappointed to find them absent. Just before leaving, the Westons arrive in a carriage. They inform Emma that Frank Churchill will arrive the next day and stay for two weeks. They promise to bring her back to Hartfield. The next day, Mr. Weston and Frank go to Woodhouse. Emma finds Frank to be a well-educated gentleman with a quick and agile wit. He flatters the elegant manners and pleasant features of Mrs. Weston. Emma is immediately attracted to Frank and imagines that he also has an interest in her. She does not realize that he had addressed Jane Fairfax the same day, as she already knew her.

0.text: Five Years Later It is now 1780. Tellson's Bank in London prides itself on being 'very small, very dark, very ugly, very incommodious. Were it more welcoming, the bank's partners believe, it would lose its status as a respectable business. It is located by Temple Bar, the spot where, until recently, the government displayed the heads of executed criminals. The narrator explains that at this time, 'death was a recipe much in vogue,' used against all manner of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher, employed by Tellson's as a runner and messenger, wakes up in his small apartment, located in an unsavory London neighborhood. He begins the day by yelling at his wife for 'praying against' him; he throws his muddy boot at her. Around nine o'clock, Cruncher and his young son camp outside Tellson's Bank, where they await the bankers' instructions. When an indoor messenger calls for a porter, Cruncher takes off to do the job. As young Jerry sits alone, he wonders why his father's fingers always have rust on them

2.text:
Five years later, it is now 1780. Tellson Bank in London takes pride in being 'very small, very dark, very ugly, very uncomfortable.' According to its partners, the banker would have lost his respectable business position if it were more welcoming. It is located near Temple Bar, the place where, until recently, the government displayed the heads of condemned criminals. At that time, 'death was a very fashionable recipe,' used against all types of criminals, from counterfeiters to horse thieves to forgers. Jerry Cruncher, an employee of Tellson's as a runner and messenger, wakes up in his small apartment in a dark part of London. He starts the day by yelling at his wife for some reason; he throws his muddy boot at her. At nine o'clock in the morning, Cruncher and his young son wait in front of Tellson Bank, waiting for instructions from the bankers. When an internal messenger calls the guard, Cruncher leaves to do the work. While young Jerry is left alone, he wonders why his father's fingers are always rusty.

0.text: Mr. Lorry arrives at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and after refreshing himself, spends the day pondering on his mission while he waits for the young woman who is Lucie Manette. She arrives believing that there is some property belonging to her late father in Paris, but Mr. Lorry breaks the news to her that her father is still alive. He is Dr. Manette who has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the last eighteen years. The French authorities have recently released him and as he was one of Tellson's Bank's clients, Mr. Lorry has been sent to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will take the responsibility for caring for her father and bringing him back to health. Lucie is taken aback at this news and she faints. A large red-haired woman runs into the room pushing Mr. Lorry aside and going to the young lady's assistance using smelling salts and cold water to revive her.

2.text: M. Lorry reaches the Royal George Hotel in Dover and, after refreshing himself, spends the day pondering his mission, awaiting the arrival of the young woman named Lucie Manette. She comes, believing there is some good to be done in Paris regarding her deceased father. However, M. Lorry informs her that her father, Dr. Manette, is still alive. He has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the past eighteen years and the French authorities have recently released him, making him a client of Tellson's Bank. M. Lorry was therefore sent to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will accept the responsibility of nursing him and accompanying him. Lucie is surprised by this news and faints. A large red-haired woman enters the room, sliding between M. Lorry and the young girl to help her with some brandy and cold water to revive her.

2.text:
In Senator's residence, Candide and Martin discover that the man is far from happy with his life or his numerous possessions. He is consistently critical or cynical about everything he owns. For instance, Rafal's paintings do not please him, Homer bores him, and he finds neither Virgil's nor Horace's nor Milton's literature particularly great. Later, when they speak alone about their visit, Candide attempts to salvage his thesis that Pococurante is the happiest of all by suggesting that there must be some pleasure in 'perceiving the weaknesses where others see beauties.' However, when Martin contradicts his thesis, Candide admits that he himself may be the only optimist regarding the idea of seeing Cungonde again.

At the senator's residence, Candide and Martin find that the man is far from content with his life or his many possessions. He is consistently critical or cynical about everything he owns. For example, Rafael's paintings do not appeal to him, Homer leaves him cold, and he finds neither Virgil's nor Horace's nor Milton's literature particularly great. Later, when they speak alone about their visit, Candide tries to defend his theory that Pococurante is the happiest of all by suggesting that there must be some pleasure in 'perceiving the weaknesses where others see beauties.' However, when Martin challenges his theory, Candide confesses that he himself may be the only optimist about the prospect of seeing Cungonde again.

0.text: Emma is thoroughly pleased with her evening at the Coles, but she is uncertain about the appropriateness of telling Frank about her suspicions about Jane or acknowledging the superiority of Jane's musical abilities. At the Coles' party, Harriet heard that Mr. Martin had dined with the Cox family, and there is a rumor that a Cox daughter would like to marry Mr. Martin. To distract and protect Harriet, Emma accompanies her on a shopping trip. They then decide to pay a visit to the Bates household and run into Frank and Mrs. Weston on their way. The visit seems to have been Frank's idea, but he offers to stay with Emma and send Mrs. Weston to make the visit on her own. Emma sends him along, knowing that he will later come see her at Hartfield, but Miss Bates then comes into the shop to ask Emma to come give her opinion of Jane's new pianoforte. In her rambling, Miss Bates reveals that Mr. Knightley has sent his last apples of the season to Jane, who is particularly fond of them.

Martin a dn chez la famille Cox, et il y a des rumeurs d'une jeune fille Cox qui veut l'pouser. Pour occuper et protger Harriet, Emma la fait faire des courses. Puis elles dcident de se rendre chez les Bates et rencontrent Frank et Mme Weston l-bas. 0.text: The Prison Door This first chapter contains little in the way of action, instead setting the scene and introducing the first of many symbols that will come to dominate the story. A crowd of somber, dreary-looking people has gathered outside the door of a prison in seventeenth-century Boston. The building's heavy oak door is studded with iron spikes, and the prison appears to have been constructed to hold dangerous criminals. No matter how optimistic the founders of new colonies may be, the narrator tells us, they invariably provide for a prison and a cemetery almost immediately. This is true of the citizens of Boston, who built their prison some twenty years earlier. The one incongruity in the otherwise drab scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison door. The narrator suggests that it offers a reminder of Nature's kindness to the condemned; for his tale, he says, it will provide either a 'sweet moral blossom' or else some relief in the face of unrelenting sorrow and gloom

2.text:
Chapter 1: The Prison Gate
This first chapter contains few actions, instead it sets the atmosphere and introduces the first of the symbols that will dominate the story. A crowd of dark and sad people had gathered before the gate of a prison in Boston in the 17th century. The massive oak door of this penitentiary is adorned with iron nails, and the building seems to have been built to hold dangerous criminals. Despite the optimistic illusions of the founders of the new colonies, they always made provisions for a prison and a cemetery almost immediately. The citizens of Boston had built their prison about twenty years ago. The only anomaly in this pessimistic scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison gate. The narrator suggests that it offers a reminder of Nature's kindness towards the condemned; for his tale, he promises either a 'sweet moral' or a relief from sadness and endless darkness.

The narrator implies that it offers a reminder of Nature's benevolence towards the condemned; for his story, he promises either a 'sweet moral' or a reprieve from sadness and endless darkness.

0.text: Tom Foster moved to Winesburg with his grandmother as a teenager. She cleans Banker White's house. Tom used to be the stable boy at the Whites' house, but because he is rather dreamy and irresponsible, he lost that position. Now, he does odd jobs and is quite happy. His grandmother comes regularly to clean his rented rooms, and he has a rather oddly disciplined approach to life experiences. He wants to do things, but he chooses specific experiences and then goes out and intentionally lives them. For example, having fallen in love with Helen White, he limits what he allows himself to think about her. One night, he decides he ought to try drinking to see what it feels like. He buys a bottle of whiskey and walks about a mile north of town, where he sits on a bank of grass and gets drunk. In his drunkenness, he goes and talks to George Willard about Helen. George is upset at first, but then they cement a bond between them. Tom decides that, now that he has been drunk, he will not need to try it again.

0.text: Emma, in her own happiness, cannot help but forgive Frank. When Knightley comes to her, she shares the letter with him. He reads the letter, telling Emma his impressions as he goes along, and he is less softened than she but willing to admit that Frank has some good qualities. He and Emma discuss her father, and he agrees that Emma cannot leave Hartfield and that Mr. Woodhouse cannot be expected to move to Donwell Abbey. He suggests that he move to Hartfield, and Emma is moved by his sacrifice. She promises to think it over, and soon likes the plan--her only sadness is that this engagement and relocation will estrange her and Harriet further

2.text: Emma, despite her own happiness, couldn't help but forgive Frank. Upon Knightley's arrival, she showed him the letter, and he read it aloud, expressing his thoughts as he went along. 0.text: Incidents In Philadelphia When the boat reached Philadelphia, Harriet earnestly thanked the captain for his kindness. He introduced her to the Rev. Jeremiah Durham, who said that Harriet could stay with him for a few days before she was able to get to New York. Fanny was placed with another family. Mrs. Durham was an extremely pleasant and solicitous woman and made Harriet feel very welcome. Harriet was awed by the bustle and diversity of Philadelphia. It was very different from her home in the south; that evening when the bells signaling a fire were heard, Harriet assumed the whole town had to get up and respond. She considered herself 'an ignorant child, just beginning to learn how things went on in great cities. After five days one of Mrs. Durham's friends decided to accompany Harriet and Fanny to New York. In their travels Harriet observed that the North was in some ways no better than the south, for colored people were treated quite differently

2.text:
In Philadelphia, upon the boat's arrival at Philadelphia, Harriet thanked the captain warmly for his kindness. He introduced her to Reverend Jeremiah Durham, who informed Harriet that she could stay with them for a few days before joining New York. Fanny was placed with another family. Mrs. Durham was a very loving and attentive woman, and Harriet felt very welcome. Harriet was surprised by the tumultuous and varied nature of Philadelphia. It was very different from her home in the south; that very evening, when the bells rang to announce a fire, Harriet thought to herself, 'a simple child, just beginning to understand how things work in big cities.' After five days, a friend of Mrs. Durham's decided to accompany Harriet and Fanny to New York. During their journey, Harriet observed that the North was no better than the South, as people of color were treated differently.

0.text: Talbot might get help, if York and Somerset could just agree. Messengers keep trying to convince them to help Talbot, and each says he can't and blames the other. We find out that Talbot's son has come out to help his father, and they may die together if York and Somerset don't find a way to help. One of the messengers, Sir William Lucy, says the feud between Somerset and York is betraying the memory of Henry V, because it's causing the English to lose what he won. Somerset finally says he'll send some horsemen, but Sir William Lucy fears it will be too late, since they will take six hours to get there. Lucy tells Somerset if Talbot is dead 'His fame lives in the world, his shame in you' , likely meaning that Talbot's courage will be remembered, but that Talbot would have been ashamed of Somerset's behavior.

2.text: Talbot could be saved, if York and Somerset managed to reach an agreement. The messengers continue to try to persuade them to help, but each one responds that he cannot and accuses the other. Then, Talbot's son arrives to aid his father, and they risk dying together if York and Somerset do not find a solution. One of the messengers, Sir William Lucy, says that the dispute between Somerset and York honors the memory of Henry V, as it causes the English to lose what he had acquired. Finally, Somerset announces that he is sending cavalry, but Sir William Lucy fears it may be too late, as they would take six hours to arrive. Lucy asks Somerset, 'Your reputation remains in the world, your displeasure with you,' which likely means that Talbot's valor will be remembered, but that Talbot was troubled by Somerset's behavior.

4.text:
English translation:

Talbot could be saved if York and Somerset had come to an agreement. Yet, messengers continued to beg for help, but each one replied that he couldn't and accused the other. Then, Talbot's son arrived to aid his father, and they ran the risk of dying together if York and Somerset hadn't found a solution. One of the messengers, Sir William Lucy, declared that the strife between Somerset and York honored Henry V's memory, as it caused the English to lose what they had gained. Eventually, Somerset announced that he was sending cavalry, but Sir William Lucy was worried that it was too late, as it would take six hours to arrive. Lucy said to Somerset, 'Your reputation remains in the world, your joy with you,' which likely means that Talbot's valor would be remembered, but Talbot was troubled by your actions.

0.text: It is summer at Longbourn; Lydia has gone to Brighton, and Mrs. Bennet and Kitty constantly complain of boredom. Mr. Bennett, as always, stays aloof and uninvolved. Elizabeth, remembering the contents of Darcys letter, is more bothered by her parents behavior than ever. She realizes they are totally mismatched and decides she will not marry until she finds someone with whom she can have a proper and supportive relationship. Unlike the bored Kitty and her mother, Elizabeth is eagerly awaiting her trip with the Gardiners. As she dreams about the northern tour, she receives a letter explaining that the trip has to be shortened to only Derbyshire. She is momentarily disappointed, for she has been looking forward to seeing the lake. The Gardiners take Elizabeth to Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner once resided. Pemberley, Darcys residence, is situated about five miles away. Elizabeth is persuaded by her aunt and uncle to visit Pemberley, since the family is away.

0.text: In order to best describe Typee life, the narrator profiles a typical day. Usually, they wake late, after the sun is up. Then they rise and bathe in a nearby refreshing stream. A light breakfast is enjoyed and then pipes are smoked. After breakfast, people tend to whatever they like. Tinor inspects her cloth and food supplies; Marheyo works on his hut; the girls adorn their hair and skin with oils. The narrator usually wanders with Kory-Kory or else sits inside. Then they enjoy a midday nap. Usually in the afternoon, the narrator goes to the Ti, where Mehevi and the other chiefs gather. Since women are not allowed in the Ti, it resembles a happy bachelor pad where the best food can be found and where the men sit around smoking and talking. After night falls, a light evening meal of 'poee-poee,' cooked breadfruit, is eaten. Native girls often dance around their huts under the moonlight. Everyone then sleeps. In general, life with the Typees resembles a continual gentle slumber, with activities in between

2.text:
To describe in detail the life of the Tyees, the narrator describes a typical day. They usually wake up late, after the sun has risen. Then they get up and bathe in a nearby cold river. A light breakfast is enjoyed, followed by smoking pipes. After breakfast, people dedicate themselves to what they love. Tinor examines his forages and supplies of food; Marheyo works on his hut; the girls oil their hair and skin. The narrator spends his mornings usually with Kory-Kory or stays inside. Then they take a midday nap. In the afternoon, the narrator goes to the Ti, where Mehevi and other chiefs gather. Since women are not allowed in the Ti, it is a place resembling a bachelor's small, joyful house, where the best food is found and men gather around their pipe bowls and discuss. After the sun has set, a small evening meal of 'poee-poee' or banana bread is eaten. Native young girls often dance around their huts under the moonlight. Finally, everyone sleeps. In general, life with the Tyees is like a long, sweet sleep, with intermediary activities.

0.text: A suspicious Nelly finds out that Cathy has been sneaking away to the Heights during her illness. Nelly forces the truth out of her, and Cathy briefly takes over the narrative. Here's Cathy's story: she goes to the Heights every night while Nelly is sick. She and Linton spend all sorts of time talking and telling stories, finding out how little in common they have. One day, she runs into Hareton, who tries to impress her with the fact that he can now read his own name above the door. She just mocks him and goes into the house. Hareton bursts in and throws a screaming Linton into the kitchen. Linton later blames Cathy for the scene, but they make up. And that's the end of Cathy's narration. Nelly promptly tells Edgar about Cathy's visits to the Heights; again, she is forbidden to go there.

0.text: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters visit the Lucas Family the day after the Meryton ball to discuss the events of the previous night. Charlotte Lucas has overheard Bingley remark that Jane is pretty and that he likes her very much. Everyone unanimously approves of Bingley, but they are in disagreement about Darcy. Most of the women criticize his standoffish behavior and haughtiness; but Charlotte defends Darcy by saying that his 'pride' is an inevitable corollary to his position in society as a 'fine young man with a family fortune'. Elizabeth agrees with her partially and says that she could have easily pardoned Darcy's pride if he had not affronted hers. Mary philosophically muses about the distinction between 'pride' and 'vanity'. The chapter also gives a brief account of the Lucas family--Sir William Lucas was a tradesman formerly and was knighted when he was a mayor. He is friendly and courteous. His wife is a kind soul, but too dull. They have many children, the eldest of whom is Charlotte, a sensible, intelligent, and practical girl.

2.text:
The Lucas Family Description - Sir William Lucas was formerly a merchant and was knighted when he was mayor. He is kind and courteous. Lady Lucas is a benevolent soul but lazy. They have several children, Charlotte being their eldest, sensible, intelligent and practical.

The Bennet women and their daughters visited the Lucas family the day after the Meryton ball to discuss the events of the previous evening. Charlotte had learned that Bingley finds Jane attractive and is completely under her spell. All agreed on Bingley's call, but they disagreed on Darcy. Many women criticized his cold demeanor and vanity; however, Charlotte defended Darcy, explaining that his 'pride' was a natural result of his position in society as a 'young man of fortune'. Elizabeth partially agreed with Charlotte, acknowledging that she might have forgiven Darcy's pride if it weren't for the offense he had given her. Mary pondered the difference between 'pride' and 'vanity'. This chapter also includes a brief description of the Lucas family - Sir William Lucas, formerly a merchant, was knighted as mayor. He is kind and polite. Lady Lucas is a charitable soul but lazy. They have several children, Charlotte, their eldest, being sensible, intelligent and practical.

4.text:
The Lucas family description - Sir William Lucas was formerly a merchant and was knighted when he was mayor. He is kind and polite. Lady Lucas is a benevolent and lazy soul. They have several children, Charlotte being their eldest, sensible, intelligent and practical.

The Bennet family and their daughters visited the Lucas family the day after the Meryton ball to discuss the events of the previous night. Charlotte had learned that Bingley finds Jane attractive and is completely under her spell. Everyone agreed with Bingley's judgment, but they disagreed on Darcy. Many women criticized Darcy's coldness and vanity; however, Charlotte defended him by explaining that his 'pride' was a natural result of his position in society as a 'young man of fortune.' Elizabeth shared Charlotte's view to some extent, acknowledging that she could have forgiven Darcy's pride if it weren't for the offense he had given her. Mary pondered the difference between pride and vanity. This chapter also includes a brief description of the Lucas family - Sir William Lucas was formerly a merchant and was knighted as mayor. 0.text: Fred is foolish enough to go back in search of his old horse, and ends up with an even worse one. He soon becomes ill, and after their regular doctor tries to help and fails, Lydgate is brought in and says he has scarlet fever. Mr. and Mrs. Vincy get angry at their regular doctor, Mr. Wrench, for failing to catch such a serious illness; Mr. Wrench is in turn angry at Lydgate for interfering, and very uncivil to the new doctor. Rumors spread about the confrontation between Mr. Wrench and the Vincys, and between Mr. Wrench and Lydgate. Various opinions and stories surface about the alleged scuffles, leaving everyone worse off as subjects of untrue gossip.

2.text:
Fred is reckless enough to go back and retrieve his old horse, and he comes out with another one that is even worse. He falls ill soon after, and when their regular doctor, Mr. Wrench, can't help, Lydgate intervenes and diagnoses measles. Mr. and Mrs. Vincy become displeased with their regular doctor, Mr. Wrench, for not having detected such a serious disease; Mr. Wrench, on the other hand, is displeased with Lydgate for interfering, and impolitely so with the new doctor. Rumors circulate about the confrontation between Mr. Wrench and the Vincys, and between Mr. Wrench and Lydgate. Opinions and stories emerge about the supposed brawls, leaving everyone more confused and irritated by the unfounded rumors.

0.text: Ellen decides to run for the doctor, and when she enters the garden, she sees Isabella's dog suspended by a handkerchief and about to die. She releases it and runs on. The doctor asks about Heathcliff, and says that he had heard that he and Isabella had been seen together the night before. This news frightens Ellen, and when she goes into Isabella's room, she finds it empty. She does not want to tell Edgar of it then, as he is busy with Catherine. The doctor tells them to keep Catherine in perfect tranquillity. They all are busy taking care of her, and eventually a maid comes to say that Isabella has run off with Heathcliff. She says that she heard it from another that they were seen together in the middle of the night. Linton says that no one is to go after them as Isabella went of her own accord. He says that they are to talk of her no more, for while he did not disown her, she disowned him

2.text:
Ellen decides to run to the doctor, and when she enters the garden, she sees Isabella's dog suspended by a scarf and about to die. She sets it free and continues. The doctor asks about Heathcliff and mentions having heard that he and Isabella had been seen together the day before. This alarms Ellen, and when she enters Isabella's room, she finds it empty. She doesn't want to tell Edgar yet, as he is occupied with Catherine. The doctor advises keeping Catherine completely calm. They are taking great care of her, and eventually, a servant announces that Isabella has left with Heathcliff. Ellen has heard it from someone else and saw them together during the night. Linton orders no one to follow them, as Isabella had run away alone. He orders not to speak of it, as she had renounced him.

0.text: Fred doesn't get to visit Mary again the next day because he develops a nasty fever overnight. His mother calls their usual surgeon, Mr. Wrench, who prescribes the wrong thing and then doesn't come back to check in on him. So Rosamond recommends that they call Mr. Lydgate , who immediately sees that it's typhoid fever . Lydgate doesn't want to step on any toes or annoy Mr. Wrench, so he tries to be nice about the fact that Wrench totally screwed up. Everyone in Middlemarch finds out about the matter, but they all hear different versions of the story. Some gossip is even getting spread that Lydgate is the illegitimate son of Mr. Bulstrode.

2.text:
Fred cannot come see Mary again the day after due to a sudden terrible fever he develops during the night. His mother calls their regular surgeon, Mr. Wrench, who unfortunately misdiagnoses it and does not return. Rosamond suggests contacting Mr. Lydgate instead, who immediately recognizes it as typhoid fever. Lydgate does not wish to intervene or disturb Wrench, so he politely suggests that she may have made a mistake. The people of Middlemarch are informed, but each one has heard different versions of the story. Rumors are even circulating that Lydgate is Bulstrode's natural son.

Gloucester is easily duped by Edmund's story, which is no doubt partly due to the scenes he has witnessed at King Lear's court. Left alone again, Edmund ridicules his father's stupidity. 2.text:
In the forest, Ivanhoe and Gurth join an assembly, and they all gather together for a feast. Ivanhoe informs Richard that his kingdom is in chaos and urges him to act quickly to reclaim it. Richard responds that he must wait until he is certain that the diverse forces he intends to rely on are aligned and prepared. Robin Hood shares Richard's concerns about his prolonged stay in the forest. He stages a scheme, making it seem as though they are threatened by a Norman attack. This sudden interruption of the feast causes Robin to reveal the deception. Realizing the urgency, Richard departs with Ivanhoe, Gurth, and Wamba towards Athelstane's castle, where Athelstane weeps for the loss of his chief.

0.text: Cinna the poet is on his way to attend Caesar's funeral when he is accosted by a group of riotous citizens who demand to know who he is and where he is going. He tells them that his name is Cinna and his destination is Caesar's funeral. They mistake him, however, for the conspirator Cinna and move to assault him. He pleads that he is Cinna the poet and not Cinna the conspirator, but they reply that they will kill him anyway because of 'his bad verses.' With Cinna captive, the crowd exits, declaring their intent to burn the houses belonging to Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius.

2.text:
Cinna the poet goes to the funeral of Julius Caesar, but is stopped by an agitated group of citizens who ask him who he is and where he is going. He answers that he is Cinna and is going to Caesar's funeral. However, they mistake him for Cinna the conspirator and attack him, intending to do harm. He repeats that he is Cinna the poet, not Cinna the conspirator, but they threaten to kill him anyway due to 'his bad poetry.' Cinna being in custody, the crowd departs, announcing their intentions to burn the houses of Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius.
